member.remarks: This method will use the and to generate automation peers for the children of these extensions. Using the and extensions instead of the template parts is also possible, but in this case no automation peers will be created if the or is used.

summary.para: Provides dedicated automation peers for custom controls of the WPF Presentation Toolkit.

For the purpose of automated UI testing, it is necessary that all WPF controls have a proper . For custom controls, this sometimes means that we have to provide a custom automation peer that allows for proper UI automation of the control. This namespace captures exactly those custom automation peers. Note that it is not necessary to have a dedicated automation peer for each custom control. Some custom controls are already automatable without the need for a custom peer.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.BackgroundBlurBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior to apply background blurring to a .
member.remarks: This behavior can be used to instruct a to apply a to its background (or, rather, to itself). This can be used, for example, to temporarily blur the background window while a modal dialog is open, in order to draw the user's attention to the dialog. In order for this behavior to have any effect, there must be a style that has a trigger that responds to changes of the exposed by this behavior; in response to this property becoming , the style must then apply the appropriate blurring effect to the .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CapsLockDetectionBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior to detect whether the Caps Lock key is on.

remarks.para: This behavior can be attached to any that needs to know whether the Caps Lock key is on. Examples are case-sensitive input fields, in particular instances. This behavior defines two dependency properties. The can be used to make a FrameworkElement aware of whether the Caps Lock key is on or off; the can be used to determine whether the Caps Lock key is actually on.

A FrameworkElement that is aware of the Caps Lock key can respond to changes in the state of the Caps Lock key in any way it wants. For example, a PasswordBox might display a message warning the user that the Caps Lock key is on.

member.summary: Exposes attached behavior that can be used to extend the functionality of any control that needs culturisation.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CultureBehavior.UseHarmonizedCultureProperty
member.summary: Identifies the UseHarmonizedCulture dependency property.
member.remarks: The default value of this property is .

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CultureBehavior.GetUseHarmonizedCulture(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets the UseHarmonizedCulture property value of a , meaning whether the date and the time are displayed using the harmonized formatting as defined by the UICC, or whether the date and time are displayed using the formatting associated with the local or operating system culture.
member.param: The to get the UseHarmonizedCultureProperty from.

remarks.para: For date display, the harmonized formatting means "dd-MM-yyyy", at least for Western cultures. For non-Western cultures such as Japanese or Russian, date formatting that is more suitable for those cultures will be used.

For time display, the harmonized formatting means "HH:mm" or "HH:mm:ss", depending on the value of the property. This means that, for the harmonized format, the 24-hour clock is always used, displaying the hours from 0 to 23. For some cultures, most notably the United States of America, this is often undesirable, as users are more familiar with the 12-hour clock which displays the hours from 1 to 12 and includes AM and PM to indicate ante meridiem (before noon) and post meridiem (after noon). If you prefer to use the local or operating time formatting, you should set the value of the current property to .
The default value of this property is , meaning that by default, both the date and the time are displayed using the harmonized formatting as defined by the UICC.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CultureBehavior.SetUseHarmonizedCulture(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the UseHarmonizedCulture property of a , meaning whether the date and the time are displayed using the harmonized formatting as defined by the UICC, or whether the date and time are displayed using the formatting associated with the local or operating system culture.
member.param: The to set the UseHarmonizedCultureProperty on.
The value to set.
member.remarks: See for a detailed explanation.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DialogWindowScaleBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior to properly scale a or a .

remarks.para: In WPF, there is an issue when you want to scale an entire window. The reason is that setting the property of a does not work, because the window chrome is not rendered by WPF but by the OS which has no knowledge about transforms. The window effectively ignores the layout transform setting. What this means is that you can easily scale the contents of a window, but not the window itself, including the title bar and other chrome. This is a well-known limitation of WPF.

This attached behavior is a way to address this issue. By setting the attached properties ScaleX and ScaleY, application builder can instruct a window or a dialog to scale itself. It is up to the window and dialog styles to pick up this attached property and implement proper scaling behavior, including scaling of the title bar.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DialogWindowScaleBehavior.GetScaleX(System.Windows.DependencyObject)
member.summary: Gets the scale factor of the X-axis of the dialog or window to which this property is attached.
member.remarks: The default value of this property is 1.0. Giving this property a decent value is the responsibility of the style.
member.param: The dependency object.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DialogWindowScaleBehavior.SetScaleX(System.Windows.DependencyObject,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the scale factor of the X-axis of the dialog or window to which this property is attached.
member.param: The dependency object.
The scale factor to be applied.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DialogWindowScaleBehavior.ScaleXProperty
member.summary: Identifies the ScaleX dependency property.
member.remarks: The default value of this property is 1.0. Giving this property a decent value is the responsibility of the style.

member.summary: Gets the scale factor of the Y-axis of the dialog or window to which this property is attached.
member.remarks: The default value of this property is 1.0. Giving this property a decent value is the responsibility of the style.
member.param: The dependency object.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.DragDropManager
member.summary: Performs the drag and drop plumbing and fires methods on the classes that inherit from and abstract classes.

remarks.para: The design is made according to the book by Pavan Podila, "WPF Control Development", Chapter 6: "Implementing Drag and Drop with Attached Properties".

The attached properties of this class are used to encapsulate the drag and drop behavior. This class defines the skeleton for the drag and drop algorithm. The specific steps of the algorithm are overridden by the subclasses which derive from the and the .

This drag and drop manager also updates the cursor to reflect the state of the drag and drop operation. If the cursor hovers over a valid drop target, this is clearly indicated, taking the associated with the drag and drop operation into account. Depending on the effects, the cursor for a valid drop target is set to or . If the cursor hovers over an invalid drop target, this is also clearly indicated by changing the cursor to .

member.example:
The following example shows how a Canvas class can be decorated with Drop and Drag Behavior in XAML. Please note that a full fledged drag and drop implementation requires much more code to be written.
<Canvas x:Name="canvas" pt:DragDropManager.DragSourceAdvisor="{StaticResource CanvasDragSourceAdvisor}" pt:DragDropManager.DropTargetAdvisor="{StaticResource CanvasDropTargetAdvisor}">

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ItemsControlBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior to govern whether an shows or hides its disabled items.

remarks.para: This attached behavior allows you to extend the functionality of any with a property that governs whether the ItemsControl should show (visualize) its disabled items. This is particularly useful if you have a requirement to hide (or, in XAML terms, collapse) the disabled menu items in a or a . By setting the value of the attached property ItemsControlBehavior.ShowDisabledItems to , you can make the Menu or the ContextMenu hide its disabled items.

Note that the use of this attached behavior is not restricted to the Menu or the ContextMenu. In principle, this attached behavior can be applied to any control that is derived from . It is up to the styles for such controls to respond to the values of the properties provided by this attached behavior, and to change their behavior and visualization accordingly.
remarks.example:
The following example shows how a control can be made to hide its disabled menu items using this attached behavior.
<ContextMenu x:Name="contextMenu" pt:ItemsControlBehavior.ShowDisabledItems="False"/>

member.param: The dependency object, which should be an .

member.summary: Sets whether the specified dependency object of a will show its disabled items.
member.param: The dependency object, which should be an .
The value to set.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ItemsControlBehavior.ShowDisabledItemsProperty
member.summary: Identifies the ShowDisabledItems dependency property.
member.remarks: By default, the value of this dependency property is , which means that, by default, any will show its disabled items. This default value is chosen because it reflects the existing behavior of the ItemsControl and its derived controls.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.OverflowBehavior
member.summary: Exposes behavior related to the customization of the overflow functionality for controls that support such functionality.

remarks.para: Some controls such as the and the support functionality that moves controls that are hosted to an overflow popup when there is not enough space to fit them on the main control. Certain aspects of this overflow behavior are subject to customization. This attached behavior class exposes exactly those properties that can be customized by integrators of the such controls.
remarks.example:
The following example shows how you can use this attached behavior to customize the tooltip of the overflow button of a .
<ToolBar x:Name="toolBar" pt:OverflowBehavior.OverflowButtonToolTip="Custom overflow button tooltip"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ScrollBarBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior that can be used to extend the functionality of any control that has a in its control template.

remarks.para: This attached behavior allows extends the functionality of any control that has a in its control template. By using the ScrollBarVisiblity attached property, the visibility of the scrollbars can be configured. This would otherwise be impossible because the ScrollViewer is hidden inside the control template, and is as such not accessible to application builders who use such as control.

This attached behavior also extends the with properties to set the width of the track of the vertical scroll bar, and the height of the track of the horizontal scroll bar. These properties are useful in cases where it is necessary to have a scroll bar that is either wider or higher than the default style allows.
remarks.example:
The following example shows how to set the visibility of the (vertical) scrollbar in a context menu. Note that it is essential to set the maximum height of the context menu, otherwise the context menu will just grow as high as it needs to be to accommodate all its items. Only if you restrain the height will the context menu show the scrollbar when there are more items than can be accommodated. In this particular example, the vertical scrollbar will be shown if there are more items than can be hosted in a context menu that is 200px high.
<ContextMenu x:Name="scrollableContextMenu" pt:ScrollBarBehavior.ScrollBarVisibility="Auto" MaxHeight="200"/>

The following example shows how to define a that has a vertical with a vertical track width of 24px, and a horizontal track height of 24px. Note that setting the track width and height only affects the track, it does not affect the width of the .
<ScrollViewer x:Name="scrollviewer" pt:ScrollBarBehavior.HorizontalScrollBarTrackHeight="24" pt:ScrollBarBehavior.VerticalScrollBarTrackWidth="24"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SelectAllOnFocusBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior to govern whether an input field such as a should select all its content (text) when it receives the focus.

remarks.para: The out-of-the-box WPF control does not select all its content (text) when it receives the focus. The control does not expose a property to set this behavior either. However, there are many situations in which the user presses tab to quickly navigate through a collection if input fields in a form. In such cases, it is often desirable that the input fields select all of their content when they receive the focus, so that the user can quickly and easily replace it with the content that he or she wants. This attached behavior class implements exactly that.
This attached behavior is primarily designed for the WPF control, but in principle it could be extended to apply to other input controls as well.
remarks.example:
The following example shows how a control can be decorated with this attached behavior.
<TextBox x:Name="selectAllTextOnFocusTextBox" pt:SelectAllOnFocusBehavior.SelectAllOnFocus="True"/>

member.seealso: How To Select All WPF TextBox Text On Focus Using An Attached Behavior
A Simple SelectAll Behavior for TextBoxes

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ThresholdBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior to define a threshold for controls.

remarks.para: controls are generally used to visualize the progress of some quantity. Sometimes, the user shall be notified when this quantity exceeds a certain threshold. For example, consider a that is used to indicate the amount of free disk space. It would be helpful to draw the user's attention when the free disk space drops below a certain threshold (or, conversely, when the amount of occupied disk space exceeds a certain threshold). This attached behavior class allows you to set a threshold on a control. It is up to the styles of the control to adapt its visualization depending on whether this threshold is exceeded or not.

This behavior exposes two attached properties called LowerThreshold and UpperThreshold. This allows users to define a lower threshold that can be used, for example, to indicate that the value indicated by the control requires attention - a battery may be less than 25% charged, the amount of occupied disk space may exceed a certain level, etc. It also allows the user to define an upper threshold that can be used, for example, that indicate that the value has become critical - a battery may require immediate charging, or the amount of free disk space may have dropped to such a low level that it is not possible anymore to store another study.

member.example:
The following example shows how a control can be decorated with this attached behavior. In this case, a lower threshold of 0.50 and an upper threshold of 0.75 is set on the progress bar with a value ranging from 0.00 to 1.00. If the lower threshold of 0.50 is reached, the progress bar will adapt its visualization to notify the user (the visualization depends on the style that is applied, but could for example mean that the progress bar changes the color of its progress indicator to orange). Similarly, if the upper threshold of 0.75 is reached, the progress bar will once again adapt its visualization to notify the user (one can think of a progress bar that turns red to indicate a critical condition that requires immediate attention).
<ProgressBar x:Name="thresholdProgresBar" Minimum="0.00" Maximum="1.00" pt:ThresholdBehavior.LowerThreshold="0.50" pt:ThresholdBehavior.UpperThreshold="0.75"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.WatermarkHelper
member.summary: Helper class to attach watermark behavior to controls that receive user input, such as the , , and controls.

remarks.para: This class can be used to attach watermark behavior to controls that expect to receive input from the end user. Typically, these are input controls like , , and . Typically, in order to increase the usability of these input controls, they display a watermark which provides a hint to the user concerning the type and the format of the data that the user is expected to type in (or provide via any other input means). The watermark is shown as long as the user is not providing any input yet. This means that, usually, the watermark disappears as soon as the input control receives the (keyboard) focus.

Unfortunately, watermark behavior is not provided out-of-the-box by any of the standard WPF input controls. That's where this custom WatermarkHelper class comes in, since it provides exactly the watermark behavior that standard WPF is lacking, in a way that is consistent across input controls.
This class currently supports the , , and controls. It is possible that, in the future, watermark support will be provided for additional user input controls.

By default, the watermark is only shown for controls that can be edited, i.e., controls that are not read-only. The reason for this is that read-only controls usually display valid content which the user cannot edit, so there is no need for a watermark. There may, however, be cases where the content of a read-only control is temporarily not available. In order to be able to show a watermark hinting at the expected content, this class provides an attached property ShowWatermarkForReadOnlyContent which can be used to display the watermark for a read-only control.

example.para:
The following example shows how the can be used. In this example, it is used to provide watermark content for a .
<TextBox x:Name="watermarkTextBox" pt:WatermarkHelper.WatermarkContent="Watermark" ... />

The following example shows how the can be used. In this example, it is used to provide watermark content for a multiline . By setting the watermark content to a that wraps its text, the watermark is also wrapped, if necessary, in the multiline text box. If you do not put the watermark content in a wrapping text block, as in the example above, the watermark will not be wrapped in the multiline text box, but will stretch over a single line only. The reason for this is that WPF implicitly wraps the content in a text block, and applies the default style to that text block. The default style may or may not have its text wrapping property set to true. In fact, the default text block style for the Experience Identity does not have it text wrapping property set to true.
<TextBox x:Name="multilineWatermarkTextBox" // // A multiline text box is a text box that has TextWrapping set to Wrap, // and AcceptsReturn to True. // TextWrapping="Wrap" AcceptsReturn="True" ...> <pt:WatermarkHelper.WatermarkContent> <TextBlock Text="You can edit me, I am a multiline watermark in a text box" TextWrapping="Wrap"/> </pt:WatermarkHelper.WatermarkContent> </TextBox>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.BrandingScreenBase
member.summary: Abstract base class for branding related user interface classes.

remarks.para: This class acts as the abstract base class for a number of branding related screens, such as the , the , and the . This abstract base class captures most of the product related properties, such as , , or , which are shared by these branding related user interface classes. It may be that a particular branding screen does not need all of these properties, because the visual design does not require it, but for the sake of uniformity, clarity, and being future-proof we recommend that all branding related screens derive from this class.

In addition to the product related properties, this abstract base class also offers the application builder the option to customize whether a derived branding screen has a close button or not. In some cases, having a close button on a branding screen can be both useful and desirable. Think, for example, of the about box. In other cases, such as a full screen startup screen or a full screen logon dialog, there should not be a close button. The and dependency properties can be used to customize this behavior.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.AdvancedToolBar.ShowsHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the header of the advanced toolbar is shown.

remarks.para: The class derives from , which in turn derives from . This means that a header can be defined for the AdvancedToolBar using one of the inherited Header, HeaderStringFormat, HeaderTemplate or HeaderTemplateSelector properties. However, if a header is defined, it should still be configurable whether this header is shown or not. For that purpose, the ShowsHeader property is introduced. It tells the style whether or not to show the header if a header is defined.

This property should not be confused with the inherited HasHeader property, which merely tells us whether or not a header is defined (by any of the four properties described above), but does not tell us whether that header should actually be shown.
The default value of this property is .

member.remarks: The default value of this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.AdvancedToolBarContainer
member.summary: Custom controls that hosts a which in turn hosts a number of s, and extends the standard ToolBarTray behavior with features like expanding/collapsing, pinning/unpinning, and a location hint.
member.remarks:
The AdvancedToolBarContainer replaces the standard WPF as the host for controls. It extends the functionality of the standard ToolBarTray with a feature to expand and collapse the controls that it hosts. It also provides pinning behavior. An unpinned advanced toolbar container can be hidden, only leaving a subtle visual hint pointing out to the user that the toolbar container can be made visible. This way, the user can hide the advanced toolbar to optimize the amount of screen real estate dedicated to other elements of the user interface, such as the display of images or other clinical data.
The AdvancedToolBarContainer expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_ToolBarTray The that the advanced toolbar container uses to host its toolbar in.
PART_ExpanderButton A that can be used to expand and collapse the toolbars that are hosted by the toolbar container.
The LocationHint is a that can be designated to indicate the location of the ToolBar when it is not visible.
member.example:
The following example shows how to create an that hosts a number of controls.
<pt:AdvancedToolBarContainer x:Name="advancedToolBarContainer"> <pt:AdvancedToolBar x:Name="viewToolBar" Header="View"> ... </pt:AdvancedToolBar> <pt:AdvancedToolBar x:Name="interactorsToolBar" Header="Interactors"> ... </pt:AdvancedToolBar> <pt:AdvancedToolBar x:Name="measurementsToolBar" Header="Measurements"> ... </pt:AdvancedToolBar> </pt:AdvancedToolBarContainer>

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.AdvancedToolBarContainer.MouseOffDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance to the nearest edge of the ToolBarContainer from the point at which the mouse is considered to be 'off' the ToolBarContainer.

remarks.para: When the ToolBarContainer is pinned, and when the mouse is off the ToolBarContainer, the opacity of the internal toolbar tray will be equal to the . When the mouse is directly over the toolbar, the opacity will be 1 and in between, the opacity increases gradually when the mouse approaches the toolbar.

When the ToolBarContainer is not pinned, the same holds, except that the mouse off opacity is considered to be 0. So the fading in and fading out is between opacity 0 and 1 instead of between MouseOffOpacity and 1.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.AdvancedToolBarContainer.ShowsHeaders
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the headers for all the advanced toolbars are shown.

remarks.para: Each that is hosted by an advanced toolbar container has a property that can be used to show or hide the header for that particular toolbar. To show or hide the headers for all the advanced toolbars at once, you can use this property on the container.
The default value of this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.AdvancedToolTip
member.summary: Custom control that offers advanced tooltip functionality.

remarks.para: This control is the same as the control. You are advised to use the InfoTip control instead of the AdvancedToolTip control.

This custom advanced tooltip control provides features that make it easier for application builders to construct tooltips for one of the most common scenarios. This scenario entails a tooltip that displays a header, which can be an icon or a text or both, and a list of pairs each consisting of a label and a value. One example in which this scenario plays out is in the tooltip for a , which often has a list of detailed information about the data that is represented by the pictorial. The information is split up into a column of labels, and a column of values corresponding to the labels. A typical example is a label that would read "Number of images", with the corresponding value listing the actual number of images found in the data represented by the pictorial.

This class provides several customization options which afford the application builder some freedom to influence how the advanced tooltip looks. Apart from properties such as , , and , which define the content of the advanced tooltip, there are other properties such as , , , and that can be used to change how the label and value columns look. It is also possible to distribute the (label, value) pairs over multiple columns, using the property.

member.summary: Updates the arrow position.
member.remarks: Currently, calling this method is only necessary when the arrow border is inside a . The final position of a popup can only be known by reacting on the event. The arrow border has to be notified of this final position by calling the Update method. When the arrow border is not inside a popup, this method does not have to be called. member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ArrowBorder.Radii
member.summary: Custom structure that holds all border thickness-independent corner radii of a .

remarks.para: This code is copied from Microsoft code.

When setting a corner radius, this corner radius applies to the middle of the border(thickness). Both the corner radius at the outer perimeter and the inner perimeter are different. Furthermore, because the border thickness can be different at all four sides, there are two corner radii for each corner. This structure holds all different corner radii for either the outer perimeter or the inner perimeter.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ColorPickerControl
member.summary: Custom color picker control.

remarks.para: This custom color picker control allows the user to pick a color. The color picker offers two different ways of doing this. First, the color picker allows the user to pick a color from several sets of predefined colors. These are called the Available Colors, the Standard Colors, and the Recent Colors. The Available Colors are, by default, equal to the set of Experience Identity annotation colors. Application builders can provide their own set of available colors if they wish. The Standard Colors are, by default, a small subset of the Experience Identity annotation colors known as the Safe Annotation Colors. These colors have been carefully selected, and tested, to be distinguishable by color-sensitive users. Finally, the Recent Colors are a small number of colors that have recently been picked. The maximum number of recent colors that the color picker remembers is configurable through the property.
Second, the color picker allows the user to pick a custom color. It uses the to implement the picking of random colors.
This color picker control is based on the one from the Extended WPF Toolkit, see .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ColorPickerDialog
member.summary: Custom dialog which allows the user to pick a color.

remarks.para: This custom dialog hosts a , which allows the user to pick a color from a list of available colors, a list of standard colors, and a list of recently used colors. In addition, the ColorPickerControl provides access to a where the user can pick any color he or she likes.

This custom color picker dialog expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_ColorPickerControl The hosted by this dialog.
PART_OkButton The OK button.
PART_CancelButton The Cancel button.
This color picker control is based on the one from the Extended WPF Toolkit, see .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Dialog
member.summary: Basic general purpose dialog class.

remarks.para: This general purpose dialog class provides various configuration options to the user. First of all, the user can configure whether or not the dialog is draggable by setting the property.

Second, the close behavior of the dialog is configurable. The user can choose whether the dialog has a Close button at all by setting the property. Once the user has decided that the dialog should have a Close button, he or she can decide whether the dialog handles the clicking of the Close button autonomously, or whether handling of the clicking is left to the application code. Typically, the latter is preferred when the application needs to be able to intervene when the user expresses the intention to close the dialog. This intervention can take the form of popping up a to give some extra information to the user, or to ask him or her to confirm the closing of the dialog. The intervention can also take the form of simply blocking the closing of the dialog until certain application specific conditions are met. If, on the other hand, the user wants the dialog to close autonomously when the Close button is clicked, this is taken care of by setting the Close button's extended to .

If the user selects a Close button to be present, this class assumes that such a button is provided by the that is applied to this control. The of this Close button must be bound to the property. When the Close button is clicked, the event is raised, giving the application the chance to intervene as described above.

In addition to the Close button, the dialog can also expose Minimize and Maximize/Restore buttons to the end users. By default, these buttons are not visible. Use the and to expose these buttons in the dialog's user interface. The implementation of the minimize and maximize/restore functionality is handled by attached behavior that is provided by the class.

Note that this dialog class does not make any assumptions about its content, other than the presence or absence of the Close, Minimize, and Maximize buttons. In particular, this dialog class does not assume that the dialog has an OK button, or any other buttons for that matter. Adding an OK button, or other buttons, and implementing the handling of clicking these buttons, is the responsibility of the application builder.

The Dialog expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_CloseButton The close button. This should always be defined in any control template for this control. The presence or absence of the close button in any particular instance of this control is governed by the property.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Clock
member.summary: Custom control that represents a clock.

remarks.para: This custom control represents a clock that is capable of displaying the date and the time. This control has several properties that influence how the date and the time are displayed. The property can be used to determine whether the clock should display the date and the time, or only the date, or only the time, or whether it should alternate between showing date and time. The property can be used to determine whether the clock should display hours, minutes, and seconds, or whether it should only display hours and minutes. If the clock displays seconds, the display will be updated every second; if the clock does not display seconds, the display will be updated every minute. The function can used to determine whether the clock should display the date and the time using the harmonized format as defined by the UICC, which means that the date format is always "dd-MMM-yyyy" (at least for Western cultures), and the time format always uses the 24-hour clock. By setting this property to , the clock ignores the harmonized date and time formatting, and uses the formats associated with the local or operating system culture instead.

The clock has the option to show an icon of a clock together with the date and the time. This icon is just a visual representation to cue the end user in on the fact that he or she is looking at a clock on the screen, rather than something else. Whether or not the clock shows this icon is configurable via the dependency property.
The Clock class does not make any assumptions about the way it is visualized. This custom control can be visualized as a digital clock or as an analog clock.

example.para:
The following example shows how the can be used. In this example, the clock is used as it comes "out of the box". This means that it will display both the date and the time, and it will display the time in hours, minutes, and seconds.
<ptc:Clock />

The following example shows how the can be used in a different way. In this example, the clock will alternate between showing the date and the time; it will display the time in hours and minutes (no seconds); and it will use the local or operating system time format instead of the harmonized time format. Finally, this clock will show a clock icon along with the date and the time.
<ptc:Clock ClockType="Alternating" Orientation="Horizontal" ShowsClockIcon="True" ShowsSeconds="False" UsesHarmonizedCulture="False"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ColorPicker
member.summary: Custom color picker control.

remarks.para: This custom color picker control allows the user to pick a color. The color picker offers two different ways of doing this. First, the color picker allows the user to pick a color from several sets of predefined colors. These are called the Available Colors, the Standard Colors, and the Recent Colors.

The Available Colors are, by default, equal to the set of Experience Identity annotation colors. You can set the to to let the available colors be equal to the broader range of Experience Identity colors (which excludes semantic colors such as the annotation colors and the notification colors). Finally, application builders can provide their own set of available colors if they wish.

The Standard Colors are, by default, equal to a small subset of the entire spectrum of Experience Identity annotation colors known as the Safe Annotation Colors. These colors have been carefully selected, and tested, to be distinguishable by color-sensitive users.

Finally, the Recent Colors are a small number of colors that have recently been picked by the user. The maximum number of recent colors that the color picker remembers can be configured through the property.
The color picker also allows the user to pick a custom color. It uses the to implement the picking of random colors.
This color picker control is based on the one from the Extended WPF Toolkit, see .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ColorSwatch
member.summary: Custom control that represents a unicolor color swatch.

remarks.para: A color swatch is a small rectangular area that has one single color. Typically, a color swatch is used to indicate the color of an element that is shown elsewhere on the screen, such as a blood vessel or a segmentation result. The color swatch then serves as a legend for the end user to interpret the colored structures or areas he or she sees on the screen.

The ColorSwatch class exposes a number of basic properties to get and set the , the , the , and the of the color swatch. Typically, the border color, the width, and the height are set by the color swatch style, while the color itself is determined by the application.

A color swatch can be editable, allowing the user to select a color by interacting with the color swatch. For example, the user can select his or her favorite color for the various segmentation results in this way. The ability to edit the color swatch's color is determined by the value of the property.
remarks.example:
The following example shows how to define a that is editable, and has its initial color set to , and its border color to .
<pt:ColorSwatch x:Name="colorSwatch" Color="Red" ColorSwatchBorderColor="Black" Width="{DynamicResource ColorSwatchWidth}" Height="{DynamicResource ColorSwatchHeight}" IsEditable="True"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DataGridBridge
member.summary: Serves as a static bridge or relay for the .

remarks.para: The Static Bridge, also called Relay, shares the property between Visual Tree elements and the elements that have been removed from the UI, due to source data changes. This class is intended to be used with the . When the user deletes a row from a data grid, one or more binding errors may be produced for each of the data grid cells of this row. This is caused by the style, which binds to properties of the parent data grid. For example, in the data grid cell style, the property may be bound to the of the data grid. Since the parent-child relation is destroyed by the removal of the data grid row (and thus all the data grid cells), the binding produces an error. This binding error can be avoided by using this static bridge.

This is a well-known WPF problem. See, for example, the following MSDN and Stack Overflow articles:
Static Bridge: Avoid Binding Error - removing a DataGrid Row with RelativeSource
How to avoid Binding Error when parent is removed
remarks.example:
The following example shows how a DataGridBridge can be used to avoid binding errors when deleting a row from the data grid.
<ResourceDictionary> <!-- Define a static resource for the DataGridBridge. --> <pt:DataGridBridge x:Key="DataGridBridge"/> </ResourceDictionary> <DataGrid x:Name="dataGrid" <!-- Bind the CanUserDeleteRows property to the DataGridBridge's property. --> CanUserDeleteRows="{Binding CanUserDeleteRows, Source={StaticResource DataGridBridge}}"> <!-- The rest of the data grid definition. --> ... </DataGrid>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DataGridColorSwatchColumn
member.summary: A custom that hosts instances in its cells.

remarks.para: This custom DataGridTemplateColumn is capable of hosting instances in its cells. The color swatches in the cells are editable. Clicking a color swatch will open a which can be used to pick a suitable color for the color swatch. Typically, this color will be related to the semantics of the color swatch; if, for example, the color swatch may correspond to the color of a particular anatomical feature shown in a viewer, or it may correspond to the color of a measurement, or it may correspond to the color of a line or a bar in a graph viewer.

This custom column class uses the convention that it binds the value of the Color property of the data items that are displayed in its cells to the color of the color swatch. This is a convention, because there is no guarantee that the data items actually have a property by this name, or that it is the correct property to use for the color of the color swatch. Future versions of this control will hopefully handle this in a better way.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DataGridExtension
member.summary: Extends the functionality of the , the , and the .

remarks.para: A feature that is missing from the standard WPF is to give a fixed width to any . The width of a data grid column can be set, but that usually does not prevent the user from changing the width interactively by grabbing the column header grippers. This extension class provides a feature to fix the width of a data grid column. This is made possible through the FixedWidth attached dependency property.

This extension class also offers a feature to retain visible row details after sorting a . Without this feature, all the row details would be collapsed after sorting the . To use this feature, set the value of the attached property to .
Furthermore, it is possible to freeze the of the vertical scrollbar inside the during the animation of the row details. To use this feature, set the value of the attached property to .

This class also offers a feature to handle mouse clicks on read-only data grid cells correctly. There is a known WPF problem with handling mouse clicks on read-only data grid cells in case multiple rows of a data grid are already selected. To use this feature, set the value of the attached property on a to .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleCollectionSpinner
member.summary: General purpose spinner control, which can be used to select a value from a specified collection of available values.

remarks.para: This class represents a general purpose spinner control, which can be used to display and select a double value from a collection of predefined double values. This spinner only accepts values that are in the collection of predefined values, and will raise an exception if an attempt is made to assign it a value that is not in that collection.

This class assumes that there is an increment ("+") and a decrement ("-") button provided by the applied style. The commands of these buttons are bound to the class commands and . The "+" button will set the spinner's value to the first value from the collection that is higher than the current value (if any); the "-" button will set the spinner's value to the first value from the collection that is lower than the current value (if any).

This class allows the user to define the unit that is displayed alongside the value. For example, the user can set the unit to "mm" or "fps", or anything that suits the need of the application he or she is building. Also, this class allows the user to define the tooltips that are used for the spinner's increment and decrement buttons. By exposing these properties, the control itself remains agnostic to what exactly the value that it visualizes represents, while giving the maximum amount of freedom to the user to customize the control's visual appearance.
A typical use case for this spinner is a frame rate control that allows the user to set the frame rate only to a set of predefined values.

member.example:
The following example shows how a DoubleCollectionSpinner can be set up in XAML to represent a frame rate control, where the manipulated unit is "frames per second", and where the acceptable frame rates bound to a collection of frame rate values, and where the spinner's current value is set to 10 fps (we assume that this is one of the acceptable frame rate values).
<ptc:DoubleCollectionSpinner Values="{Binding FrameRateValues}" Value="10.0" Unit="fps" IncreaseToolTip="Faster" DecreaseToolTip="Slower"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleSpinner
member.summary: General purpose spinner control, which can be used to choose a value within a specific range.

remarks.para: This class represents a general purpose spinner control, which can be used to display and select a double value. This class derives from , which means that the values that can be selected are limited to the range specified by the base class. The base class uses the properties and to determine the range of selectable values.

The DoubleSpinner expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_TextBox A that displays the current value of the double spinner. Can also be used as a value entry field is the dependency property is set to .
PART_DecreaseButton A that can be used to decrease the value of the double spinner. Clicking this button will decrease the value by an amount specified by the property. Clicking this button will respect the value of the property, as well as the value of the property.
PART_IncreaseButton A that can be used to increase the value of the double spinner. Clicking this button will increase the value by an amount specified by the property. Clicking this button will respect the value of the property, as well as the value of the property.
So, this class assumes that there an increase ("+") and a decrease ("-") button are provided by the applied style. The commands of these buttons are bound to the class commands and .

This class allows the user to define the unit that is displayed alongside the value. For example, the user can set the unit to "mm" or "fps", or anything that suits the need of the application he or she is building. Also, this class allows the user to define the tooltips that are used for the spinner's increment and decrement buttons. By exposing these properties, the control itself remains agnostic to what exactly the value that it visualizes represents, while giving the maximum amount of freedom to the user to customize the control's visual appearance.

member.example:
The following example shows how a DoubleSpinner can be set up in XAML to represent a frame rate control, where the manipulated unit is "frames per second", and where the acceptable frame rate ranges from 5 fps to 60 fps, and where the frame rate can be increased or decreased in steps of 0.5 fps:
<ptc:DoubleSpinner Minimum="5" Maximum="60" SmallChange="0.5" Unit="fps" IncreaseToolTip="Faster" DecreaseToolTip="Slower"/>

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleSpinner.StringFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the string format used to display the spinner's Value.

remarks.para: Any template that is used to style this spinner control should make sure that it applies this string format to the presentation of its value. Furthermore, it should make sure by applying the proper binding that the property returns the value with the proper string format applied to it.
By default, the value of this property is "0.0", which means that the spinner's value is displayed with a precision of one decimal place.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleSpinner.FormattedValue
member.summary: Gets the formatted version of the , based on the .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleSpinner.IsReadOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the value should be read only.
member.remarks: By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleSpinner.IsValueDisplayed
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the spinner's Value should be displayed.

remarks.para: This property can be used to create a spinner that does not display its current value. Such a spinner will only display an increase and a decrease button. Changes to the current value are not reflected directly in the user interface of the spinner, but might possibly lead to observable changes elsewhere in the user interface. This property is mainly used to create spinners that occupy a minimum amount of screen real estate, and for which it is completely clear to the user what will happen when he or she presses the increase or decrease button.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleSpinner.IsCyclic
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this control can cycle through its values.

remarks.para:
Cycling means:
When the value is equal to the minimum value and the decrease button is pressed, the value will become the maximum value.
When the value is equal to the maximum value and the increase button is pressed, the value will become the minimum value.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ExtendedCalendar
member.summary: Custom that adds extra functionality to the standard .
member.remarks:
This control extends the by:
Preventing the calendar from capturing the mouse.
Adding commands for selecting today, navigating to the previous month, navigating to the next month, navigating to the previous year and navigating to the next year.
An attached IsTodayButtonVisible property is added too. With this, a regular , a and a can all incorporate a Today button in their template. The reason that this property is an attached property is that a generates a regular Calendar in its code. Adding functionality to this regular Calendar means exposing attached properties in the ExtendedCalendar. For situations in which a normal calendar is necessary (instead of a DatePicker), it is best to use the ExtendedCalendar.
Adding functionality to add week numbers inside a . You can set the AreWeekNumbersVisible property on a , a and a . The CalendarWeekRule property is used to control the way the first week of the year is determined. This property can also be set on all three controls. Finally, the read-only WeekNumber properties are used to get the week numbers of the current month.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ExtendedCalendar.OnPreviewMouseUp(System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs)
member.summary: Prevents the from capturing the mouse.
member.remarks: When selecting a date, the CalendarItem would capture the mouse. This is very annoying because when one would want to interact with another control outside the calendar (like opening a combo box), one should first give that control focus. Capturing the mouse is only necessary when a popup is opened (like the DatePicker does). Clicking outside the popup should close the popup and for this reason, a popup should indeed capture the mouse.
member.param: The event arguments.

member.summary: Handles changes in the AreWeekNumbersVisible property.
member.remarks: This property may only be set on a , (or ) or on a . The week numbers are always displayed inside a Calendar; in both situations, we have to subscribe to the event of the (internal) Calendar. This is because a DatePicker does not expose a DisplayDateChanged event like the Calendar does.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ExtendedStatusBar
member.summary: Represents a status bar with extended functionality. It is derived from the standard WPF control.
member.remarks: The ExtendedStatusBar provides some advanced features on top of the standard WPF control. First of all, the ExtendedStatusBar has the option to show a . By default, the clock will be shown, but this is customizable through the property. Also, the ExtendedStatusBar can display up to two users who are interacting with the system. These are called the "primary user" and the "secondary user". The intention here is that the "primary user" identifies the user who is logged on to the system, while the "secondary user" identifies another user who may be looking over the shoulder, either from a local or a remote location.
member.example:
The following example shows how the can be used. Here, the ExtendedStatusBar shows a digital clock (by default), as well the names of the primary and secondary users. It also shows a custom , which in this example is a , but in general this could be anything.
<ptc:ExtendedStatusBar x:Name="extendedStatusBar" Grid.Row="2" Grid.ColumnSpan="3" PrimaryUser="Dr. Blair" ShowsPrimaryUser="True" SecondaryUser="Dr. Hamilton" ShowsSecondaryUser="True"> <ptc:ExtendedStatusBar.Clock> <ptc:Clock x:Name="digitalClock" Style="{DynamicResource StatusBarDigitalClockStyle}" ClockType="TimeOnly"/> </ptc:ExtendedStatusBar.Clock> <StatusBarItem> <ProgressBar x:Name="progressBar" Value="50" Width="100"/> </StatusBarItem> </ptc:ExtendedStatusBar>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ExtendedTabControl
member.summary: Custom that makes sure that the tab items are retained, and are not reloaded every time a switch to another tab item is effectuated.
member.remarks: By default, a WPF tab control destroys and recreates its tab items each time a switch to another tab is made. This is detrimental to the performance of switching between tab items. To mitigate this problem, a suggestion made by various StackOverflow articles is followed, which introduces an extension of the standard tab control.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.FormattedDoubleSpinner
member.summary: Dedicated that formats its value given the number of decimal places.

remarks.para: This custom control extends the with a dependency property that can be used to specify the number of decimals that are used to display the double spinner's value. For example, if the double spinner's value is 1.2345, and the DecimalPlaces property is set to 2, the value will be displayed as 1.23.
This custom control exists for historical reasons. A better way to implement this would be to define attached behavior for the class.

member.example:
The following example shows how the can be used. In this example, a double spinner is defined with a range from 0 to 10, and the number of decimal places is set to 2. The step size is set to 0.1.
<ptc:FormattedDoubleSpinner Minimum="0" Maximum="10" SmallChange="0.1" DecimalPlaces="2"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.HelpDialog
member.summary: Custom that serves as the help dialog for an application.

remarks.para: The HelpDialog is a custom dialog dedicated to presenting help content to the end user. To harmonize the way in which help content is presented to the user, the help dialog has a help icon (question mark) in the title bar, and optionally has a close button in the title bar as well.

The HelpDialog is a special kind of dialog. It differs from the in that the HelpDialog usually presents static information to the end user that is meant to be read only, and does not require any action or choice from the user. The MessageBox, on the other hand, usually presents information that requires the user to confirm that he or she has read it, or that requires the user to make an explicit choice.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.IconLabelButton
member.summary: Custom control which represents a button that is visualized as an icon with a label next to it.

remarks.para: The IconLabelButton is one of several different button types that were first designed to be used in the context of the , but that possibly have a much wider applicability. This custom button is designed to be a custom control for the convenience of the application designer, who can explicitly choose to use this custom button when needed.

The IconLabelButton introduces two properties that replace the regular Content property. These properties allow the user to set both the and the , which are displayed next to each other. The Content property must not be set, to prevent the content of this custom control to be defined more than once.

The IconLabelButton distinguishes itself from the primarily in the way it is visualized. The IconLabelButton visualizes its Icon as a button, and its Label as a label next to the button. To the user, it seems that the Label stands apart from the Icon, even though the entire area covering both the Icon and the Label is clickable.

member.example:
The following example shows how to define an IconLabelButton that triggers a function to create a vessel path segmentation. Note that the Icon and the Label properties are set, while the Content property is ignored.
<pt:IconLabelButton Icon="{StaticResource VesselSegmentationIcon}" Label="Segment Path" Width="180"/>

member.summary: Custom control which represents a button that is visualized as an icon with a text, both within the borders of the button.

remarks.para: The IconTextButton is one of several different button types that were first designed to be used in the context of the , but that possibly have a much wider applicability. This custom button is designed to be a custom control for the convenience of the application designer, who can explicitly choose to use this custom button when needed.

The IconTextButton introduces two properties that replace the regular Content property. These properties allow the user to set both the and the , which are displayed next to each other. The Content property must not be set, to prevent the content of this custom control to be defined more than once.
The IconTextButton distinguishes itself from the primarily in the way it is visualized. The IconTextButton visualizes both its Icon and its Text within the borders of the button.

member.example:
The following example shows how to define an IconTextButton that triggers a function to create a vessel path segmentation. Note that the Icon and the Text properties are set, while the Content property is ignored. The text can be wrapped by setting the property. In the example below, this property is set such that the text will not be wrapped.
<pt:IconTextButton Icon="{StaticResource ConfigurationIcon}" Text="Settings" TextWrapping="NoWrap" Width="180"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.InfoTip
member.summary: Custom control that offers info tip functionality.
member.remarks: An info tip is a special kind of tooltip that has the ability to provide more elaborate information in a customizable way to the user. The InfoTip is the same as the , but we prefer the InfoTip as this is more in line with the UICC and Philips Design specifications, both for Experience Identity (EI) and for Design Language System (sDLS). But at heart, the InfoTip is just another name for the AdvancedToolTip, and does not offer any additional functionality or configuration options. For the sake of consistency, though, we recommend that you use the InfoTip class everywhere in your code.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnControl
member.summary: Custom that serves as the body of a logon dialog for an application. The control can also be hosted in other UI components. All logon functionality is provided by this control.

remarks.para: The LogOnControl allows the user to enter his or her username and password credentials. The credentials can be validated, and access to the rest of the application or system can be granted or denied. The LogOnControl gives a warning when the Caps Lock key is turned on, since this is a common source of providing invalid credentials.

The LogOnControl expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_UserNameTextBox A where the user can enter his or her username.
PART_PasswordBox A where the user can enter his or her password credentials.
PART_OkButton A that acts as the OK button. Usually, this button has the text "Log on" instead of "OK", but its function is that of the OK button in the sense that it allows the user to confirm the credentials he or she entered.
PART_CancelButton A that acts as the Cancel button.
PART_ShutdownButton A that acts as the Shut Down button.
The Cancel and Shut Down button should be mutually exclusive. A logon control either has an OK (Log on) and a Cancel button, or it has an OK and a Shut Down button. In case the logon control has a Shut Down button, the command that is executed when this button is clicked can be set via the property.

In order to guarantee the confidentiality of the data that is entered by the user, the password is exposed only as a . This means that the password is encrypted for privacy when being used, and deleted from computer memory when no longer needed. This LogOnControl does not expose a human readable version of the password that is not secure.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnControl.CredentialsValidator
member.summary: Gets or sets the event handler used to validate the username and password.
member.remarks: The is a delegate, which allows application builder to plug in a method that provides custom credentials validation logic. The logon control provided by the WPF Toolkit does not implement credentials validation, because this often involves passing the credentials to an authentication service and so on. So, it is preferred to leave the actual implementation of the credentials validation up to the application builder.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnControl.UserName
member.summary: Gets or sets the username.

remarks.para: This property can be used to retrieve the username after the user has provided his or her credentials. The username is stored as a normal , unlike the password which is stored as a .

This property can also be used to set a predefined username for the logon dialog. This can be useful if a "Remember me" feature is implemented, and the user expects his or her username to be already filled in; it can also be useful in scenarios where several users share the same username, or where the users decide they want to have a single username to gain access to the system. This property should be used with care.
The default value of this property is .

member.seealso: Dependency property associated with this property.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnControl.MaxUserNameLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum length for usernames to be handled by this LogOnControl.

remarks.para: This property allows the user to choose the maximum length for the username field. It in the same way as the property. This means that a value of zero (0) means that there is no limit to the length of the usernames that are handled by this LogOnControl.
The default value of this property is 0, i.e., by default no maximum length restriction applies to the usernames to be handled by this LogOnControl.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnControl.MaxPasswordLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum length for passwords to be handled by this LogOnControl.

remarks.para: This property is meant to expose the to the users of the LogOnControl. This property behaves in the same way as the property. This means that a value of zero (0) means that there is no limit to the length of the passwords that are handled by this LogOnControl.
The default value of this property is 0, i.e., by default no maximum length restriction applies to the passwords to be handled by this LogOnControl.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnDialog
member.summary: Custom that serves as the logon dialog for an application.

remarks.para: The LogOnDialog allows the user to enter his or her username and password credentials. The credentials can be validated, and access to the rest of the application or system can be granted or denied. The LogOnDialog gives a warning when the Caps Lock key is turned on, since this is a common source of providing invalid credentials.

In order to guarantee the confidentiality of the data that is entered by the user, the password is exposed only as a . This means that the password is encrypted for privacy when being used, and deleted from computer memory when no longer needed.

The LogOnDialog expects the following named template parts to be defined in its control template:
PART_LogOnControl The that hosts the actual logon user interface.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnResult
member.summary: Enumeration defining the various results of providing logon credentials.
member.remarks: The values defined by this enumeration can be used to communicate whether the logon credentials that are provided by a user, such as the username and the password, are valid or invalid. In case the logon credentials are invalid, a distinction can be made between a generally invalid condition, or a more specific invalid condition such as an incorrect username or an incorrect username/password combination.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnResult.Valid
member.summary: The credentials provided by the user are valid.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnResult.Invalid
member.summary: The credentials provided by the user are invalid.
member.remarks: This result can be used to provide a non-specific message of invalidity. For example, if it is not known whether the username or the password is incorrect, or perhaps if this distinction is not relevant, this generic invalid result provides an option to communicate that something is wrong without specifying exactly what is wrong.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnResult.InvalidUserName
member.summary: The credentials provided by the user contain an invalid username.
member.remarks: This result can be used to provide a specific message of invalidity. In this case, the specific message states that the username is invalid.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.LogOnResult.InvalidPassword
member.summary: The credentials provided by the user contain an invalid password, or a password that does not match the username.
member.remarks: This result can be used to provide a specific message of invalidity. In this case, the specific message states that the password is invalid.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MedicalDeviceClassification
member.summary: Enumeration defining the various types of medical devices as they are categorized by the European Union (EU).

remarks.para: The Medical Device Classification is described in the document "MEDICAL DEVICES: Guidance Document - Classification of Medical Devices", MEDDEV 2.4/1 Rev. 9, June 2010, issued by the European Commission DG Health and Consumer, Directorate B, Unit B2 "Cosmetics and medical devices". The document can be found here:
The Medical Device Classification is further worked out in the "STANDARD Labelling of Products", Version 5, a Philips Healthcare standard. This document can be found here:

The Medical Device Classification determines whether the product should be identified with a label (CE label) and an accompanying text. This identification is to be displayed on the Startup Screen, the About Box, etc.

member.seealso: MEDICAL DEVICES: Guidance Document - Classification of Medical Devices

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MessageBar
member.summary: Custom control representing a message bar, which is a kind of combo box filled with instances. Each message bar item contains a message text, an icon, and a (nullable) timestamp.

remarks.para: A "transient" message is a message that is shown for (at most) a specified amount of time ( milliseconds). This message is replaced by a newer transient message, if that newer message arrives before the number of milliseconds defined by has passed.

A "permanent" message, on the other hand, is a message that is shown for a much longer time, possibly with no upper time limit. It can be temporarily replaced by a newer transient message, but as soon as the transient message expires, the permanent message is shown again. A permanent message is only removed when a newer permanent message arrives. So, there will always be at most 1 permanent message. A permanent message can also be explicitly removed by the application. This is usually done when the condition that is reported in the permanent message no longer exists.

Transient messages will be used to report transient events, i.e., events that only require the users attention for a limited period of time. Permanent messages will be used to report semi-permanent events, i.e., events that require the users attention for a longer period of time.
An example of a transient message might be Printing the images for patient X has succeeded. An example of a permanent message might be Battery low.
The MessageBar uses a to visualize its MessageBarItem, and to allow the user to view the data represented by the MessageBarItems. By default a "transient" message is shown for milliseconds.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MessageBox
member.summary: Custom that serves as a WPF variant of the MessageBox.

remarks.para: This custom MessageBox class is introduced to bridge the gap between the functionality of the Win32 MessageBox and the WPF MessageBox. The former allows the user to define more button combinations, such as Abort/Retry/Ignore, and Retry/Cancel, that are not provided by the standard Microsoft WPF MessageBox. The API of this custom class mimics the WPF API as closely as possible. Only where it offers functionality that is not supported by the standard Microsoft WPF MessageBox does it revert to using Win32 types.

As a result of this, there are 16 overloaded Show methods; ten of these are copies of Show methods that you will find on the Microsoft WPF MessageBox API; the other six are copies of Show methods that you will find on the Microsoft Win32 MessageBox. These methods differ only from the standard Show methods in that they take a parameter to define the owner of the message box, rather than an . This makes the Win32 Show methods compatible with the WPF API, and users do not have to go through the trouble of converting a WPF window to a Win32 window handle. The overloaded methods are chosen in such a way that preference is given to the WPF API, while still enabling the functionality of the Win32 API.

In addition to providing overloaded Show methods for the WPF and Win32 APIs, this class also provides overloads that take an parameter to represent the owner of the message box. These overloads are intended to be used ONLY for establishing interoperability between traditional WinForms applications and WPF. In particular, these overloads should be used to show a WPF message box from a WinForms applications, while passing the WinForms host on to the message box as its owner. Please ensure that you use these overloads for interoperability purposes only.

Application programmers are advised to stick with the WPF Show methods as much as possible. In practice, this means that you should always use the WPF Show methods unless your message box needs the Abort/Retry/Ignore or Retry/Cancel button combinations.

To use the MessageBox from the Presentation toolkit you must add the following using alias. This will prevent name clashes with the existing WPF MessageBox and the existing WinForms MessageBox.
using MessageBox = Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MessageBox;

member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to show a MessageBox providing only the message box text. Note that we use the WPF API in this case. The message box that is shown will only have an OK button. It will not have a caption or a message box icon.
MessageBoxResult messageBoxResult = MessageBox.Show( "The patient data has been successfully exported.", );

The following example demonstrates how to show a MessageBox that presents a choice that the user needs to confirm or deny using the Yes or the No button. The message box has a caption and displays a question mark as its message box image. The owner of the message box is passed in as a parameter. Note that we use the WPF API in this case, which is always preferred over the Win32 API.
var owner = Window.GetWindow(this); MessageBoxResult messageBoxResult = MessageBox.Show( owner, "Do you want to close this window?", "Close Dialog", MessageBoxButton.YesNo, MessageBoxImage.Question );

The following example demonstrates how to show a MessageBox that presents a choice that the user needs to confirm or deny using the Retry or the Cancel button. The message box has a caption and displays an information icon as its message box image. Note that we use the Win32 API in this case, because the Retry/Cancel button combination is not supported in the WPF API. Note also that the owner window is passed in as a rather than as a .
var owner = Window.GetWindow(this); MessageBoxResult messageBoxResult = MessageBox.Show( owner, "It is currently not possible to complete the operation." + "Do you want to retry or cancel the operation?", "Warning", MessageBoxButtons.RetryCancel, MessageBoxIcon.Information );

member.summary: Method to click the default button when the MessageBox is operating in .
member.remarks: This method can be used to programmatically click the default button. This is especially useful in automated testing situations, where human intervention is not possible or not desirable. This method will execute a click of the default button, as a result of which both the and the properties will be set. This method will not close the message box. For that, you need to either call the or the , depending on which API you used to show the message box.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MessageBox.AreFontPropertiesSetByOwner
member.summary: Gets whether the font related properties are set by the owner of the message box.

remarks.para: Typically, a message box will have the same values for font related properties such as font family and font size as its owner. However, it is not always the case that the owner of a message box is set. In this case, the style for the message box needs to be able to determine suitable default values for the font related properties. It can use this property to inspect whether the font related properties are actually provided by the owner or not.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MessageBox.InteractiveMode
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the MessageBox is in interactive mode.

remarks.para: If the MessageBox is in interactive mode, calls to any of the overloaded Show methods are not blocking; instead, the application programmer has the responsibility to close the MessageBox programmatically by calling one of the static or methods. Which of these methods needs to be called depends on whether the MessageBox was shown using one of the WPF API Show methods, or one of the Win32 API Show methods.
If the MessageBox is not in interactive mode, calls to any of the overloaded Show methods will block until the user closes the MessageBox by clicking one of its buttons.

Setting the InteractiveMode to is particularly useful in testing scenarios, where it is not possible to gather input from a real, human user, and all interaction with the MessageBox must be done programmatically.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBar
member.summary: Custom control that provides basic movie and navigation functionality.

remarks.para:
The MovieBar expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_MainContainer The main container that hosts the movie bar. This template part captures and handles and events for the movie bar.
PART_Ellipse An that serves as a hint for users to access the movie bar functionality in case the movie bar is "hidden". The ellipse is a subtle visual hint or indication that the movie bar is there, and hovering over it will reveal the full movie bar functionality.
PART_FrameRateContainer The container for the frame rate functionality of the movie bar. This template part captures and handles and events for the frame rate functionality of the movie bar.
PART_FrameRateSlider A that allows the user to change the frame rate at which the movie is played.
PART_PlayPauseButton A that allows the user to toggle between playing and pausing the movie.
PART_RecommendedFrameRateThumb A that represents a visual indication of the recommended frame rate for a given set of images.
PART_MovieBarHitTester A transparent that is used as hit-tester when the movie bar is in unpinned state. This corresponds to what is called the target area in the sDLS movie bar specification.
PART_LegsBackground
PART_LeftLegContent Container on the movie bar with content placed on the left side of the movie bar.
PART_Core Container on the movie bar with content placed in the middle of the movie bar.
PART_OverflowButton The movie bar overflow button. Clicking this button will open the overflow popup panel, which hosts all the controls that do not fit on the movie bar itself.
PART_Pin The movie bar pin button. If the movie bar is pinned, the auto-hide behavior is disabled. See the dependency property.

The user can navigate through the available frame rate values. These are either determined by the and properties, which allow for a continuous range of frame rate values; or they are determined by explicitly setting a collection of available frame rate values using the property, which allows the application builder to define a fixed set of discrete frame rate values.

Navigation through the frame rate values is either cyclic, or it respects the boundaries set by the minimum and maximum frame rate values. This latter mode is the default, as it corresponds most naturally to the user's expectations of this behavior. The default behavior can be changed by setting the value of the property to .

This class provides basic movie functionality that is not specialized for any modality or data type. If you need specific movie functionality for your modality, or for your type of clinical data, you can implement a dedicated movie bar that derives from this basic movie bar, or you can implement one from scratch.

The WPF Presentation Toolkit provides a number of dedicated, specialized movie bars:
MRMovieBar Movie bar specialized for MR data sets.
Movie bar specialized for X-ray data sets.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBar.FrameRateValues
member.summary: Gets or sets the available frame rates.

remarks.para: The default value is an empty collection.

When the collection is not empty, the values of the and properties will correspond to the smallest and largest values in the collection of frame rate values. This collection will be leading, and explicitly setting the minimum and maximum frame rate to values outside the collection will have no effect.
Furthermore, when the collection of frame rate values is not empty, the and are ignored.
This property may not be set to .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBar.IsFrameRateCyclic
member.summary: Gets or sets whether adjusting the frame rate can be done in a cyclic fashion.

remarks.para: If the value of this property is , the user can navigate through the available frame rate values in a cyclical fashion. This means that, if the user reaches the , navigation through the frame rates will automatically resume starting from the . Conversely, if the user reaches the , navigation will resume starting from the .

If, on the other hand, the value of this property is , the user will not be able to navigate beyond the or the ; rather, the minimum and the maximum constitute hard boundaries on the navigation capabilities of the user.
