member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarArranger
member.summary: Custom panel that lays out (arranges) the .

remarks.para: The MovieBarArranger is a helper control for the that takes care of measuring and arranging the movie bar's template child controls.
The movie bar consists of a core (PART_Core) that hosts the play/pause button. This core part is measured and arranged by another dedicated helper control, the .

In addition to the core part, the movie bar has a left leg (PART_LeftLegContent), a right leg (PART_RightLegContent), a pin button (PART_Pin), and an overflow button (PART_OverflowButton). It is the responsibility of the MovieBarArranger to host these child controls, measure them, and arrange them. If all the parts fit in the available space, they will all be arranged in the first layer of the movie bar, in other words they will all be visible. If there is not enough space to fit all the parts, the left and right legs will be collapsed, and their content will be placed on an overflow popup panel that pops up when the overflow button is clicked. Note that the overflow button will only be visible if the left and right leg are not. The pin button will always be visible, unless the movie bar is configured to not expose the pin button - there are use cases where the movie bar is always pinned, so the pin button does not need to be there.

Note that this movie bar arranger relies on the presence of certain template parts in the movie bar style, corresponding to the child elements that need to be arranged:
PART_Core The core part of the movie bar, hosting the play/pause button.
PART_LeftLegContent The left leg of the movie bar, hosting custom content on the left side of the movie bar core.
PART_RightLegContent The right leg of the movie bar, hosting custom content on the right side of the movie bar core.
PART_Pin The pin button, which can be used to set the pinning or auto-hide behavior of the movie bar.
PART_OverflowButton The overflow button, which is shown if there is not enough space available to show the entire movie bar content. The controls that cannot be shown are placed on an overflow popup panel that is shown when the overflow button is clicked.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarButton
member.summary: Custom that is used to implement repeat behavior for various buttons that are used in the context of the .
member.remarks: The is a control that hosts several buttons dedicated to navigating through a collection of images, such as Next Image, Previous Image, Next Series, Previous Series, etc. From a usability point of view, it may be better for these buttons to expose repeat behavior, so that the user can quickly navigate by just keeping the repeat button pressed. This custom MovieBarButton does exactly that. It can be customized to expose repeat button behavior by setting the property to true.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarCoreArranger
member.summary: Custom panel that lays out (arranges) the central part (core) of the .

remarks.para: The MovieBarCoreArranger is a helper control for the that takes care of measuring and arranging the movie bar core's template child controls.

The movie bar consists of a core (PART_Core) that hosts the play/pause button. In addition to the core, the movie bar can have custom content to the left and the right of the core (PART_LeftLegContent and PART_RightLegContent), a pin button (PART_Pin), and an overflow button (PART_OverflowButton). The movie bar as a whole is measured and arranged by the class. This MovieBarCoreArranger class is only responsible for measuring and arranging the core.

The movie bar core itself consists of a number of elements, which should be defined as template parts in the movie bar's style:
PART_PlayPauseButton The play/pause button which is the most basic feature of the movie bar.
PART_Ellipse The ellipse (or rather the circle) that hosts the play/pause button.
PART_LeftCoreContent The default movie bar controls to the left of the play/pause button. Typically, these include controls to navigate to the previous image/frame and the previous series/run.
PART_RightCoreContent The default movie bar controls to the right of the play/pause button. Typically, these include controls to navigate to the next image/frame and the next series/run.

member.seealso: Custom panel Class that layouts the MovieBar

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.summary: Measures the size of the left leg, the play/pause button, and the right leg of the movie bar core.
member.param: The available size that this element can give to child elements. Infinity can be specified as a value to indicate that the element will size to whatever content is available.
member.returns: The size that movie bar core needs during layout, based sizes of the left leg, the right leg and the play button. If the full version fits in the availabeSpace, the size of the full version is returned, otherwise the size of the play button only.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarScalingLevel
member.summary: Enumeration defining the various movie bar scaling options.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarScalingLevel.ExtremelySmall
member.summary: Only PART_PlayPauseButton

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarScalingLevel.VerySmall
member.summary: Only PART_PlayPauseButton and PART_OverflowButton
member.remarks: There is only space for the play/pause button + the overflow button, i.e., the pin button does not fit. The play/pause button is shown. All other movie controls are moved to the overflow popup. The pin button is moved to the overflow popup (if pinning is required). The overflow button is shown. This is not specified in the Visual Guide, but needs to be addressed anyway.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarScalingLevel.Small
member.summary: Additionally: PART_Pin
member.remarks: The movie bar does not fit in the available space, and neither does the movie bar core, but the pin button does. The play/pause button is shown. All other movie bar controls are moved to the overflow popup. The pin button is shown (if pinning is required). The overflow button is shown. This is called "MovieBar used on Small Image" in the Visual Guide

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MovieBarScalingLevel.Medium
member.summary: Additionally: parts PART_LeftCoreContent and PART_RightCoreContent.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MRMovieBar
member.summary: Custom control that provides basic movie and navigation functionality that is suitable for MR data.

remarks.para:
The MRMovieBar expects various additional named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_PreviousImageButton
The previous image button. Clicking this will navigate to the previous image in the movie.
PART_MovieNavigationDimensionSplitButton
The movie dimension split button. Clicking this will change the movie navigation dimension.
PART_NextImageButton
The next image button. Clicking this will navigate to the next image in the movie.
PART_MovieDirectionSplitButton
The movie direction split button. Clicking this will change the movie direction.
PART_LeftCoreContent The container for the PART_PreviousImageButton.
PART_LeftWingBackground
An item that is the background for the left wing or leg. Does not contain any items.
PART_RightCoreContent
The container for the PART_MovieDirectionSplitButton, PART_FrameRateIndexSlider, PART_Pin and PART_OverflowButton.
PART_RightWingBackground
An item that is the background for the right wing or leg. Does not contain any items.
PART_FrameRateIndexSlider
The frame rate index slider. Clicking the button shows a slider that can change the frame rate of the movie.
This class provides movie functionality that is specialized for MR.

The user can navigate through the available frame rate values. These are either determined by the and properties, which allow for a continuous range of frame rate values; or they are determined by explicitly setting a collection of available frame rate values using the property, which allows the application builder to define a fixed set of discrete frame rate values.

Navigation through the frame rate values is either cyclic, or it respects the boundaries set by the minimum and maximum frame rate values. This latter mode is the default, as it corresponds most naturally to the user's expectations of this behavior. The default behavior can be changed by setting the value of the property to .

This class provides basic movie functionality that is specialized for Mr. If you need specific movie functionality for your modality, or for your type of clinical data, you can implement a dedicated movie bar that derives from this basic movie bar, or you can implement one from scratch.

The WPF Presentation Toolkit provides a number of dedicated, specialized movie bars:
Movie bar specialized for MR data sets.
Movie bar specialized for X-ray data sets (this class).

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Provides custom WPF controls that are specific to the medical (imaging) domain. Each of these controls represents a dedicated control as defined by the User Interface Competence Center (UICC) that is not provided out-of-the-box by WPF.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NavigationItem
member.summary: Custom that represents a navigation item, which is hosted in a .

remarks.para: A NavigationItem is a custom TabItem that should always be hosted in a NavigationPane. It consists of a , a , and an , which are visualized according to the various states of the navigation pane (Expanded or Collapsed, List Mode or Tiles Mode, etc.)

A NavigationItem can have content, which is displayed if the navigation pane that hosts the navigation item is expanded, and the navigation item is selected. If the navigation pane is collapsed, there is not enough space to show this content, which is usually a panel with multiple controls. As an alternative, the content is hosted in a which is shown when the user clicks an (already) selected navigation item. To allow for maximum flexibility, it is not enforced that the regular content must be the same as the collapsed popup content. To this end, a NavigationItem has a dependency property called , which can be used to define the content of the popup that is associated with a collapsed navigation item. The Popup that is used to host this content is expected to exist as a template part with the name "PART_CollapsedContentPopup".

The popup that shows the collapsed content by default disappears if the user clicks anywhere outside the popup. The discoverability of this feature can be problematic, though, as not all users are inclined to click just anywhere on the screen. As a further aid to the user, the popup can display a close button. By default, this close button will be shown, but this can be configured using the dependency property. The close button is expected to exist as a template part with the name "PART_PopupCloseButton".

In addition to the Popup, the user can also define regular content to be displayed in the navigation item's collapsed state. This regular content is usually a vertical row of buttons, which somehow summarize the full content of the navigation item.
A detailed explanation of the capabilities of the NavigationPane and the NavigationItem can be found in the Philips Design document "Side Panel - Task Guidance and Global Tools".
remarks.example:
The following example shows how to define a NavigationItem in the context of an expanded NavigationPane. The navigation item represents the Segmentation task in a clinical application, and its regular content consists of two NavigationItemStepExpanders.
<pt:NavigationPane x:Name="navigationPane"> <pt:NavigationItem x:Name="segmentationNavigationItem" NavigationIndex="1" Label="Segmentation" Icon="{StaticResource TaskGuidanceSegmentationIcon}"> <StackPanel> <NavigationItemStepExpander x:Name="redoStepExpander" IsExpanded="False" HeaderText="Redo segmentation"> <StackPanel> <Button Content="Draw Path"/> <Button Content="Segment Path"/> </StackPanel> </NavigationItemStepExpander> <NavigationItemStepExpander x:Name="verifyStepExpander" IsExpanded="true" HeaderText="Verify segmentation"> <StackPanel> <Button Content="Verify landmarks"/> <Button Content="Verify Path"/> </StackPanel> </NavigationItemStepExpander> </StackPanel> </pt:NavigationItem> </pt:NavigationPane

The following example shows how to define the same NavigationItem in the context of a collapsed NavigationPane. The content of the navigation item, which is the same as in the previous example, is now assigned to the PopupContent property, such that it will be shown in a popup when the user clicks the (selected) navigation item.
<pt:NavigationPane x:Name="navigationPane"> <pt:NavigationItem x:Name="segmentationNavigationItem" NavigationIndex="1" Label="Segmentation" Icon="{StaticResource TaskGuidanceSegmentationIcon}"> <pt:NavigationItem.PopupContent> <NavigationItemStepExpander x:Name="redoStepExpander" IsExpanded="False" HeaderText="Redo segmentation"> <StackPanel> <Button Content="Draw Path"/> <Button Content="Segment Path"/> </StackPanel> </NavigationItemStepExpander> </pt:NavigationItem.PopupContent> </pt:NavigationItem> </pt:NavigationPane

remarks.para: A detailed explanation of the capabilities of the NavigationPane and the NavigationItem can be found in the Philips Design document "Side Panel - Task Guidance and Global Tools".

A NavigationItemStep can show context-sensitive help content in a dialog. To this end, a NavigationItemStep has a dependency property called , which can be used to define the content of this dialog. The help ToggleButton that opens this dialog is expected to exist as a template part with the name "PART_HelpToggleButton". The help content is shown in a . member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NavigationPane
member.summary: Custom that represents a navigation pane, which hosts instances.

remarks.para: A detailed explanation of the capabilities of the NavigationPane and the NavigationItem can be found in the Philips Design document "Side Panel - Task Guidance and Global Tools".

The navigation items hosted by this navigation pane can be displayed either in "List" or in "Tiles" mode. This is configurable through the property. In "List" mode, all navigation items are visualized in the same way, regardless of the number of items. In "Tiles" mode, however, the visualization of the navigation items depends on the number of items - for small numbers of items (2, 3) the navigation items are relatively wide, whereas for larger numbers of items (4, 5) the navigation items are not so wide. If there are more than five items, ideally a scrolling mechanism should be provided to horizontally scroll through the available items. Unfortunately, such a mechanism has not been implemented yet.

Because the visualization of the navigation items depends on their number, this class keeps track of the number of visible items through the property. It is necessary to distinguish this from the total number of visible and invisible items. Changes to this property are notified through the event, which allows template builders to bind to this property.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NavigationPaneExpander
member.summary: A custom that can be used to host a in the sidebar.

remarks.para: A navigation pane expander can displays its navigation items in three different View Modes. In the "List" view mode, the navigation items are displayed as a vertical list; in the "Collapsed List" view mode, the navigation items are displayed as a collapsed vertical list; in the "Tiles" view mode, the navigation items are displayed as a horizontal collection of tiles. These view modes are similar to the ones found in Microsoft Explorer.

It is possible to configure the navigation pane expander through the dependency property to either enable or disable use of the "Tiles" view mode. If the navigation pane expander is configured to enable use of the "Tiles" view mode, this view mode can be activated through the property. This property will have no effect if the navigation pane expander is configured to disable use of the "Tiles" view mode. The property can be used to show small tiles instead of large tiles, which is the default. In the "Tiles" mode, it is possible to show a header which contains the title of the selected navigation item. This behavior is configurable through the property.

The style associated with this NavigationPaneExpander is expected to retemplate the . The retemplated header should provide a visualization of the and properties, which are defined on the NavigationPaneExpander control. This makes it easier for application builders to use the NavigationPaneExpander, because they only have to set these two properties instead of constructing a local piece of user interface content that is assigned to the property.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SidebarExpander
member.summary: A custom that supports collapsed content.

remarks.para: The SidebarExpander is a specialized Expander that can be used to host collapsible content in a sidebar, which is typically located at the left side of the user interface. A famous example of a sidebar is the Microsoft Outlook Navigation Pane.

In addition to the functionality offered by the standard Expander, the SidebarExpander allows the separate hosting of a footer. This means that the SidebarExpander has a property to set the header, content, and footer. In addition, all three of these can be visualized differently in the expanded and the collapsed state. For example, the content may be visualized as a full-fledged panel in the expanded state, while it may be visualized as a vertical list of buttons or labels in the collapsed state. In general, the sidebar will not have enough real estate to visualize its entire content in the collapsed state. This is addressed by presenting a different, limited visualization in this state.

Expanding and collapsing the SidebarExpander may or may not use animation. This can be configured at design-time or even at run-time through the property. Using animation may enliven the user experience, but it comes at the expense of less performance, and it may cause other issues with other user interface elements that must respond to the animation.

Using animation can only be configured at the level of the entire control. This means that every part of the SidebarExpander that supports animation is either animated, or it is not. It is currently not possible to configure the use of animations at the level of individual user interface elements that are part of the SidebarExpander.

There are use cases where the SidebarExpander should always be expanded, and collapsing it should not be an option that is offered to the end user. To facilitate these use cases, this class provides the property.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether animation is used to expand or collapse the sidebar.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NavigationPaneExpander.CanUseTilesProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

remarks.para: By default, the value of this property is , which means that by default the navigation can be shown both as tiles and as list items.
Changing the value of this property does not necessarily result in a change of the view mode ("List" or "Tiles"). To change the view mode, you can use the property.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NavigationPaneExpander.UsesTilesProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

remarks.para: By default, the value of this property is , which means that by default the navigation items are shown as list items rather than as tiles.

Changing the value of this property to will only result in a change to the view mode (from "List" to "Tiles") if the associated property has the value . If this property has the value , it will not be possible to change the view mode to "Tiles", and setting the current property will have no effect.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NotificationBox
member.summary: Custom that represents a notification.

remarks.para: A NotificationBox is used to present a single notification to the user. Such a notification consists of a , a , and (optionally) an . A notification presented in a notification box has a transitory nature. This means that it will only be shown for a short while. After that, it looses its relevance, and it is removed again or replaced by newer, more urgent notifications.

Typically, a sequence of notification boxes are hosted by a . As this container class takes care of showing and removing notification boxes, application programmers typically do not have to deal with the NotificationBox class directly. The only thing application programmers need to do is add new notifications to the container class, according to the business logic of the application.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.NotificationBoxContainer
member.summary: Custom control that hosts instances.
member.remarks: A NotificationBoxContainer can host any number of NotificationBox instances. These are added by the application by calling one of the overloaded AddNotification methods. The application programmer has some control over where the notification boxes pop up by manipulating the , , and properties. Furthermore, the application programmer can define the width and the (maximum) height of the notification boxes through the and properties. These properties are defined as such because, for aesthetic reasons, all notification boxes should in principle have the same width, but their height should be determined by the content. If the height of the content exceeds the maximum notification height, a vertical scroll bar will be made available to allow the user to reveal the full content.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PatientBar
member.summary: Custom control used to display patient demographics and to manage multiple opened patients.

remarks.para:
The PatientBar expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_Root A that serves as the root of the visual tree that is defined in the patient bar's control template. It is at the level of this root that the visual states of the patient bar are defined.
PART_PatientBarGrid A that hosts the patient bar proper.
PART_PatientInfoPopup A that displays secondary patient information, such as patient details, patient demographics, or visit details. The information displayed in this popup is defined by the property, and is visualized according to the .
PART_BackgroundButton A that represents the background of the patient bar. It captures mouse clicks and opens the popup that displays secondary patient information, or executes the that is configured for the patient bar.

The Patient Bar also expects various named template visual states to be defined in its control template. These template visual states are:
VISUALSTATE_PatientBarVisible A that corresponds to the patient bar being visible. The visual state should describe a transition (animation) from the state where the patient bar is hidden.
VISUALSTATE_PatientBarHidden A that corresponds to the patient bar being hidden. The visual state should describe a transition (animation) from the state where the patient bar is visible.

There are various ways in which the visualization of the patient bar can be customized. Most importantly, the look and feel of the entire patient bar can be customized using the and properties. The first of these will change how the primary patient data is visualized in the main part of the patient bar. The second of these will change how the secondary patient data in the popup that is identified by the PART_PatientInfoPopup template part is visualized. Please note that the patient bar's style is expected to define a default primary patient data template, but not a default secondary patient data template. The definition of the secondary patient data template is always left up to the application builder.

If you do not want to replace the entire , there are various options for more fine-grained customization of the visualization. For example, the patient bar's default primary patient data template uses different icons to indicate that a patient is in "acquisition mode" or in "viewing mode". Which of these two modes a patient is in can be configured through the property. It is possible to configure the so-called patient type icon that indicates "acquisition mode" by setting the property. Similarly, it is possible to configure the icon that indicates "viewing mode" by setting the property. If you do not want the patient bar to display a patient type icon at all, you can configure this by setting the property.

A further fine-grained option is to provide custom content that will be hosted in the default primary patient data template. By default, the primary patient data template will display patient related information such as the patient name, the patient ID, the date of birth, and the gender. If you need to display additional information that is specific to your system or application, you can provide any custom content you like through the property. This custom content will typically be hosted to the right of the patient related information, and to the left of the allergies and alerts indication.

The patient bar has the ability to display information on whether the currently selected patient has any allergies or whether there are any medical alerts relevant for this patient. This information is communicated to the patient bar through the and properties. In case there are no (known) allergies or medical alerts, appropriate texts are displayed to convey this to the end user. Text resource for these cases are provided out-of-the-box, by can be customized using the , , and properties. Typically, a warning indicator is displayed in the patient bar's primary patient data template in case there are allergies or medical alerts. Detailed information on the allergies and medical alerts is disclosed in the secondary patient data template and the tooltip.

The patient bar also has the ability to display information on any non-clinical alerts that are relevant for the currently selected patient. An example of such a non-clinical alert is an alert drawing the end user's attention to the fact that the patient data has been merged from two or more different sources (RIS, HIS, PACS, etc.). Information concerning these non-clinical alerts is communicated to the patient bar through the and properties.

The patient bar can use an animation to support changes to the data it displays. For example, the patient bar can use an animation to draw the user's attention to the fact that another patient has been selected. By default, these animations are not enabled, but you can enable them by setting the dependency property to .

Interaction with the patient bar is possible via command binding and matching events:
CloseCommand / CloseClick
ActivateCommand / Click

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PatientBar.CustomContent
member.summary: Gets or sets the (optional) custom content of the patient bar.

remarks.para: Typically, the custom content is placed to the right of the "fixed" content, such as the patient name, patient ID, date of birth, and the gender. It is placed to the left of the allergies and alerts indication.

Setting this property is only effective if you stick to using the default . The primary patient data template takes this property into account, and hosts the custom content. If you want to deviate in a more significant way from what the default primary patient data template provides, you can override the entire template.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PatientBar.InteractionMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin of the interactive area relative to the patient bar.
member.remarks: When the mouse is over the interactive area, and the patient bar is checked, the drop down indicator should become visible. A InteractionMargin of 50,0,100,25 means that the interactive area extends 50 DIU's compared to the left edge of the patient bar, 0 DIU's compared to the top of the patient bar, 100 DIU's compared to the right of the patient bar and 25 DIU's compared to the bottom of the patient bar, DIU's being Device Independent Units.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PatientsButton
member.summary: Custom control that is used to provide access to the collection of patients.

remarks.para: Typically, the PatientsButton is used together with the to provide access to the collection of patients, and to allow the user to see which patient is currently selected, and to select a new patient. The PatientsButton is typically displayed in the top left part of the screen.

The PatientsButton derives from , and fixes the and properties such that the PatientsButton by default displays the Patient List icon, and the localized "Patients" label. The application builder can still override the default values of these properties, but this is not recommended.

According to the Visual Guide 1.1, it should be possible for the PatientsButton to act as the default button, and display a glow which indicates this state. To accommodate for this requirement, the PatientsButton is defined as a separate class, which exposes the dependency property. The reason to do this is that PatientsButton derives from IconLabelToggleButton, which in turn derives from , and the standard WPF toggle button does not expose an IsDefault property.

member.example:
The following example shows how to define a PatientsButton that acts as the default button.
<pt:PatientsButton x:Name="patientsButton" IsDefault="True"/>

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PatientsButton.IsDefault
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether a is the default button.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Pictorial
member.summary: Custom control that represents a Pictorial in a . A pictorial typically visualizes one clinical data element, such as a series, a run, a movie, a report, etc.

remarks.para: A pictorial is a small, card-like representation of a clinical data element such as a series, a run, a movie, a report, etc. Typically, a pictorial shows a representative element of the data set, such as an image that is representative for an entire series or an entire run. In addition to this "pictorial representation", a pictorial can be decorated with additional text or icons that reveal more information about the data set. Taken together, this information facilitates recognition of the data set by the user, and allows him or her to select the right data for further viewing, processing, or diagnosis.

There are two sets of icons that can be used to decorate a pictorial. The first set tells the user something about the kind or type of data that is represented by the pictorial. Does the pictorial represent a series, a movie, a report, etc. The second set tells the user something about the status of the data. Has the data been sent to a printer, has the data been exported to an archive, etc.

The following properties are related to the kind or type of data:
Indicates the type of data represented by the pictorial.
Icon that visualizes the type of data represented by the pictorial.
Icon that visualizes whether the data is suitable for an advanced analysis application.
Icon that provides additional, custom information about the type of data represented by the pictorial. This allows application builder to inject their own custom type information.
Another icon that provides additional, custom information about the type of data represented by the pictorial. This allows application builder to inject their own custom type information.

The following properties are related to the status of the data:
Indicate the status of the data associated with the pictorial w.r.t. exporting that data to an archive. Has export started, is export in progress, has export completed, has export failed, etc.
Indicate the status of the data associated with the pictorial w.r.t. exporting that data to physical media (CD, DVD, Blu-Ray, USB). Has export to media started, is export to media in progress, has export to media completed, has export to media failed, etc.
Indicate the status of the data associated with the pictorial w.r.t. printing that data. Has printing started, is printing in progress, has printing completed, has printing failed, etc.
Icon that provides additional, custom information about the status of the data represented by the pictorial. This allows application builder to inject their own custom status information.
Another icon that provides additional, custom information about the status of the data represented by the pictorial. This allows application builder to inject their own custom status information.

member.summary: Gets or sets the placement of the pictorial header relative to the pictorial content.

By default, the value of this property is Bottom, i.e., the pictorial header is placed below the pictorial content.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the pictorial should visualize its "currently displayed" state.

remarks.para: If this property is set to , the "currently displayed" state will be visualized using the .
The default value of this property is , indicating that, by default, a pictorial is not displayed.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Pictorial.IsFlagged
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the pictorial is flagged.

remarks.para: A pictorial can be flagged, meaning that the data associated with the pictorial is singled out for future reference - for example, the data may be interesting for further analysis, diagnosis, or may be flagged to be exported or printed.

Use this property to indicate that all the data associated with the pictorial is flagged. If only some, but not all, the data associated with the pictorial is flagged, consider using the property instead.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Pictorial.IsPartiallyFlagged
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the pictorial is partially flagged.

remarks.para: A pictorial can be flagged, meaning that the data associated with the pictorial is singled out for future reference - for example, the data may be interesting for further analysis, diagnosis, or may be flagged to be exported or printed.

Use this property to indicate that only some, but not all, of the data associated with the pictorial is flagged. If all the data associated with the pictorial is flagged, consider using the property instead.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PictorialDataType
member.summary: Enumeration defining the various pictorial data types.

remarks.para: The pictorial data type is used to indicate what kind of data a pictorial is representing. Typically, the type of data is visualized on the pictorial in the form of an icon, to give a visual hint to the end user which will facilitate selecting the right pictorial for viewing or further processing.

Typically, the conversion of the pictorial data type to a corresponding icon is done by a converter. The WPF Presentation Toolkit provides a default converter out-of-the-box, called the . This converter covers all the pictorial data types listed by this enumeration.

member.example:
The following example shows how to use the PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter with the PictorialDataTypeToIconConverterExtension inside a binding:
<Image Source="{Binding SomePictorialDataTypeValue, Converter={pt:PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter} }"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PictorialIndex
member.summary: Custom control that represents a Pictorial Index, which is a sorted list of instances.

remarks.para: The Pictorial Index uses a to visualize its Pictorials, and to allow the user to select the data represented by the Pictorials.
The Pictorial Index extends the standard with two properties, and , that can be used to influence the automatic selection behavior of the Pictorial Index.

This custom pictorial index control expects the following named template parts to be defined in its control template:
PART_ScrollViewer The that hosts the content of the pictorial index. This allows the user to scroll through the pictorials if there are so many that they can't be all shown at the same time.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PreviewMouseMoveWeakEventManager
member.summary: Custom that is used to subscribe to the event, using a weak reference.
member.remarks: By subscribing to the event without using a strong reference, memory leaks can be avoided. One example which uses this class is the which subscribes to the event of its parent . When this would be done using a strong reference, the window would hold a reference to the ToolBarContainer. This way, the ToolBarContainer would never be disposed. A memory leak would exist. This memory leak is avoided by the intervention of the WeakEventManager.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Resizer
member.summary: Represents a control with a single, resizable piece of content.

remarks.para: The Resizer is a custom that allows itself to be resized. The default template places a WPF in the lower-right-hand corner of the content. The user can drag the size grip in order to resize the Resizer and its content.
The and properties facilitate control over the resize grip inside the Resizer.

The code in this file was originally written by Kent Boogaart, and could be found on his blog at . Unfortunately, it seems that his blog is no longer active, and this hyperlink does not lead to an active page anymore. We have not been able to find a suitable replacement for this original blog post. The code has been modified to meet the HSDP Clinical Platform quality requirements.

member.example:
The following example shows how a Resizer can be used to provide a resizable TextBox:
<ptc:Resizer> <TextBox/> </ptc:Resizer>

The following example shows how a Resizer can be used to provide resizable content inside a Popup:
<Popup> <ptc:Resizer> <TextBlock>Here is the content</TextBlock> </ptc:Resizer> </Popup>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScrollViewerShadowOverlay
member.summary: Extends the by adding support for s.
member.remarks:
This class limits the shadow thickness by checking the offsets of the associated :
If the HorizontalOffset is 0, the shadow on the left side should not be visible.
If the HorizontalOffset is equal to the ScrollableWidth, the shadow on the right side should not be visible.
If the VerticalOffset is 0, the shadow on the top side should not be visible.
If the VerticalOffset is equal to the ScrollableHeight, the shadow on the bottom side should not be visible.
Once scrolling occurs and content disappears at a certain side, then the shadow on that side will gradually appear.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ShadowOverlay
member.summary: Custom that can render a "shadow" on each of the four sides of the control on which this element is overlaid.
member.remarks: This class renders shadows by painting a rectangle with a certain brush and a certain opacity mask. Because of the opacity mask, the rectangle gradually blends into its background, giving it the appearance of a shadow. Since this element has no background of its own, casting drop shadows instead of painting four separate rectangles is not an option.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScrollViewerShadowOverlay.CoerceShadowThickness(System.Windows.Thickness)
member.summary: Coerces the property.
member.remarks:
This method coerces the shadow thickness by checking the offsets of the associated :
If the horizontal offset is 0, the shadow on the left side should not be visible
If the horizontal offset is equal to the ScrollableWidth, the shadow on the right side should not be visible
If the vertical offset is 0, the shadow on the top side should not be visible
If the vertical offset is equal to the ScrollableHeight, the shadow on the bottom side should not be visible
Once scrolling occurs and content disappears at a certain side, then the shadow on that side will gradually appear.
member.param: The desired shadow thickness.
member.returns: The final shadow thickness.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ShrinkableStackPanel
member.summary: Custom to deal with space limitations.
member.remarks:
This custom deals with space limitations by shrinking the children in the descending order of their width (widest to smallest). The total process of shrinking the children is called the shrinking process. Every time the ShrinkableStackPanel is measured, this process is executed. This means that no state information is kept between subsequent measurements. However, state information is kept between a measurement and arrangement.
This custom only supports the Horizontal orientation.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.Spinner
member.summary: General purpose spinner control, which can be used to select a value from a collection of values.

remarks.para: This class represents a general purpose spinner control, which can be used to display and select an item from a collection of items. It is implemented as a custom , which means that it has a SelectedItem, SelectedIndex, an ItemTemplate to visualize the selected item, etc.

This class assumes that there is a 'SelectNext' and 'SelectPrevious' button provided by the applied style. The commands of these buttons are to be bound to the class commands and . Pressing the SelectNext button selects the next item in the list until the last item is selected. When the control can cycle (IsCyclic == true), the selection does not stop at the last item, but proceeds with the first item. Likewise, pressing the SelectPrevious button selects the previous item in the list until the first item is selected. When the control can cycle (IsCyclic == true), the selection does not stop at the first item, but proceeds with the last item.

This class allows the user to define the tooltips that are used for the spinner's SelectNext and SelectPrevious buttons. By exposing these properties, the control itself remains agnostic to what exactly the item that it visualizes represents, while giving the maximum amount of freedom to the user to customize the control's visual appearance.
A typical use case for this spinner is a frame rate control that allows the user to set the frame rate only to a set of predefined values.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButton
member.summary: Custom that implements the combination of a with a drop down.
member.remarks: Like a regular , the SplitButton extends the by adding functionality to make a button default.

example.para:
The following example shows how to instantiate a SplitButton using static content and hard-coded items. The necessary data template is omitted in this example.
<ptc:SplitButton StaticContent="{Binding ToolIcon}"> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource ZoomIcon}"/> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource InteractorIcon}"/> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource ViewIcon}"/> </ptc:SplitButton>

It is also possible to use data binding. The split button items can be bound to the ItemsSource property, and an item template can be provided to visualize the items. The example below illustrates this by binding the ItemsSource to a collection of tool icons, and visualizing each item as an icon. It is not necessary to explicitly set the selected index to 0, this is done by default. Of course, the selected index can be set to a different value if needed.
<ptc:SplitButton ItemsSource="{Binding ToolIcons}"> <ptc:SplitButton.ItemTemplate> <DataTemplate> <Image Source="{Binding ImageSource}" Width="{DynamicResource ToolBarItemImageWidth}" Height="{DynamicResource ToolBarItemImageHeight}"/> </DataTemplate> </ptc:SplitButton.ItemTemplate> </ptc:SplitButton>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase
member.summary: A custom control, deriving from , that implements the concept of a "split button": a combination of either a , a or a , with a drop down button that provides access to a collection of elements.

remarks.para: A split button is a combination of a basic button - called the action element - and a drop down button next to it. There are two ways to open this drop down: either by pressing the action element and holding it for a while, or by clicking the drop down button.

By default, the content of the action element will be bound to the selected item. However, if one of the four properties is set, the corresponding default binding with the selected item will be overridden. In other words, to set static content on the action element (content that doesn't change when the selection changes), just set the property, optionally in combination with the , or . If one of the four static properties is set, the split button is said to be in 'static mode'.

This custom split button expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_ActionElement The split button's action element, which is the element that displays either the selected content or the static content that is associated with the split button. This element is active in the sense that clicking it will provide access to the split button items.
PART_DropDownButton The split button's drop down button. Clicking this drop down button will provide access to the split button items. The drop down button is expected to be a , so that it is possible to monitor its state. The property is introduced to make it possible to monitor from the outside whether the drop down button is checked or not.
PART_Popup The drop down that contains the items in the split button. This part is "inherited" from the control from which this split button is derived. The drop down determines its own width based on the widest split button item and the value of the property. If you want the drop down to have the exact same width as the split button itself, you can set the property to .

Just like in a menu, it is sometimes useful to group the split button items that are part of the split button's drop down content. To facilitate this grouping, it is possible to host items next to s. Again, just like in a menu, the separators will be displayed so as to convey the idea of grouped sets of items.

KNOWN ISSUE This control derives from the standard WPF control. In the ComboBox dropdown list, the and keys can be used to navigate through and select the options. For this derived class, this does not work well, since the commands that are associated with the options in the dropdown are not properly executed. Therefore, using these keys to navigate through the dropdown does not give the desired result.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase.OnClick
member.summary: Called when the action element is clicked.
member.remarks:
This method will raise the event and execute the default of the split button. It does the same for the selected item container if the following holds:
The split button is not in static mode
The selected item is its own item container, i.e. is a .
If the split button is data bound, then this last condition will not hold. In this case, the selected item may not have an associated item container; this is the case when the popup didn't open yet. Therefore, if the split button is data bound, the user should use the default . By default, the is bound to the selected item. With this parameter, the user can easily execute the associated command in the execute handler.

member.remarks: When an item is clicked, the split button should also raise its event and execute its , even if it is in static mode. This should occur, after the click event and command of the item are processed.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase.IsDropDownButtonChecked
member.summary: Gets whether the toggle button associated with the "PART_DropDownButton" template part is checked.

remarks.para: This property is introduced to manage dependencies between the various constituent elements of the split button. For example, the "PART_ActionElement" template part might want to update its visualization based on whether the "PART_DropDownButton" template part is checked or not.
This property only has a public getter. The setter is protected because we do not want this property to be set from the outside.
The default value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase.ShowToolTipForItems
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a is shown for each individual item of the split button.

remarks.para: It is possible to let each individual split button item display a . However, sometimes this is not useful, for example of the tooltip is the same as the text that is already displayed in the item, or does not add any useful information. In such a case, it should be possible to disable the display of the tooltips at the level of the split button itself, i.e., not at the level of the individual items. This property is intended to be used for exactly that purpose.
The default value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase.ActionElementWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the action element (PART_ActionElement) of the split button.
member.remarks: The default for this property is . It is the responsibility of the style to give a sensible value to this property.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase.DropDownButtonWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the drop down button (PART_DropDownButton) of the split button.
member.remarks: The default for this property is . It is the responsibility of the style to give a sensible value to this property.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonBase.UseSplitButtonWidthForDropDown
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the width of the split button should be used to determine the width of the drop down.

remarks.para: The split button presents its items in a drop down. This drop down determines its width autonomously, based on the width of the largest item, and the value of the dependency property. However, in some cases, we want the width of the drop down to be the same as the width of the split button itself, so that the drop down aligns neatly with the split button itself. To achieve this, this property can be set to .
The default for this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonItem
member.summary: Custom that serves as an item container for a split button.

remarks.para: The SplitButtonItem is a control that can be hosted by any control that derives from . Just like with a regular , it is possible to attach a command to a SplitButtonItem. To support this, the SplitButtonItem class implements the interface.

Due to an issue in the class, the enabled state of the content has to be set to whenever the enabled state of the SplitButtonItem is set to . The same issue can be reproduced with a regular . The issue is the following:

When the split button shows the selected item in its action element, it needs to use a to visually duplicate the selected item when that selected item is a . This is necessary because UIElement's can only have one visual parent. This visual brush is used to paint a . The content of the action element binds with the and this element contains the rectangle.

The already makes sure that the action element is disabled when initially, a disabled item (container) is selected. Due to this disabling, the internal rectangle which uses the visual brush is also disabled.

However, whenever items are created by creating SplitButtonItem's explicitly, and the selected SplitButtonItem is disabled, then the visual brush does not respect this initial disabled state and paints the content of the action element like it is enabled. This is probably because the enabled state of the content of the selected SplitButtonItem is not set to explicitly; it is set on the SplitButtonItem. Only when the drop down is opened, the enabled state of the content will be updated, and the content of the action element will look disabled.

One solution to this issue is to set the enabled state of the content of the SplitButtonItem explicitly, whenever the enabled state of the SplitButtonItem is set to . This way, the visual brush will eventually duplicate content that already looks disabled.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitButtonMenuItem
member.summary: Custom that mimics the behavior and the visual style of a regular to some extent.

remarks.para: This class makes it easier for application builders to define split button items that behave and look like regular menu items. For this, some of the more commonly used properties of the regular are mimicked. For example, it is easy to define a split button item using its and properties.
This class is derived from , and as such it supports commands through its implementation of the interface.

example.para:
The following example shows how to instantiate a that has four SplitButtonMenuItem elements, and one .
<pt:SplitToggleButton x:Name="splitToggleButton" StaticContent="{StaticResource ToolIcon}"> <pt:SplitButtonMenuItem Header="Undo" Icon="{StaticResource GeneralUndoIcon"/> <Separator Style="{DynamicResource SeparatorSplitButtonStyle}"/> <pt:SplitButtonMenuItem Header="Cut" Icon="{StaticResource GeneralCutIcon"/> <pt:SplitButtonMenuItem Header="Copy" Icon="{StaticResource GeneralCopyIcon"/> <pt:SplitButtonMenuItem Header="Paste" Icon="{StaticResource GeneralPasteIcon"/> </pt:SplitToggleButton>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitRadioButton
member.summary: Custom that implements the combination of a with a drop down.

remarks.para: This class doesn't mimic a yet in the sense that it doesn't uncheck other 's or 's that have the same parent or group name. This functionality will be added later. Until that time, the application should do this unchecking.

example.para:
The following example shows how to instantiate a SplitRadioButton using static content and hard-coded items. The necessary data template is omitted in this example.
<ptc:SplitRadioButton StaticContent="{StaticResource ToolIcon}"> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource ZoomIcon}"/> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource InteractorIcon}"/> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource ViewIcon}"/> </ptc:SplitRadioButton>

Using data binding is also possible by using the ItemsSource. It is not necessary to set the selected index to 0, this is done by default.
<ptc:SplitRadioButton ItemsSource="{Binding ToolModels}" IsChecked="True"> <ptc:SplitRadioButton.ItemTemplate> <DataTemplate> <Image Source="{Binding IconSource}" Width="24" Height="24" RenderOptions.BitmapScalingMode="HighQuality"/> </DataTemplate> </ptc:SplitRadioButton.ItemTemplate> </ptc:SplitRadioButton>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.SplitToggleButton
member.summary: Custom that implements the combination of a with a drop down.
member.remarks: Like a regular , the SplitToggleButton extends the by adding functionality to check or uncheck the action element. This control is commonly found in tool bars in which a tool can be selected from a list. The checked state of the split button then indicates whether the tool is active at that moment or not.

example.para:
The following example shows how to instantiate a SplitToggleButton using static content and hard-coded items. The necessary data template is omitted in this example.
<ptc:SplitToggleButton StaticContent="{StaticResource ToolIcon}"> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource ZoomIcon}"/> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource InteractorIcon}"/> <ptc:SplitButtonItem Content="{StaticResource ViewIcon}"/> </ptc:SplitToggleButton>

Using data binding is also possible by using the ItemsSource. It is not necessary to set the selected index to 0, this is done by default.
<ptc:SplitToggleButton ItemsSource="{Binding ToolModels}" IsChecked="True"> <ptc:SplitToggleButton.ItemTemplate> <DataTemplate> <Image Source="{Binding IconSource}" Width="24" Height="24" RenderOptions.BitmapScalingMode="HighQuality"/> </DataTemplate> </ptc:SplitToggleButton.ItemTemplate> </ptc:SplitToggleButton>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.StaggeredContentControl
member.summary: Custom control which displays its content in a staggered way, like a deck of cards.

remarks.para: A StaggeredContentControl visualizes its content in a staggered way. This can be thought of as a deck of cards, where only the top card is entirely visible, and the underlying cards are only partly visible. A staggered content control can, for example, be used to visualize a pictorial that represents a data set with multiple images or frames. Visualizing such a pictorial as a staggered content control conveys the impression that the pictorial represents a collection of images or frames rather than just one image or frame.

A StaggeredContentControl has one additional properties which can be used to provide and visualize information on the data represented by the control. This property is the property, which can be used to indicate the number of items represented by the draggable container content control. Typically, for a dragged pictorial, this property indicates the number of pictorials.

The exception to this rule is a tab container that hosts only one tab, and (possibly) does not have a header. In that case, the border serves no real purpose, and this property can be used to remove it from the tab container visualization.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.TabContainerItem
member.summary: Custom control which represents a tab container item, i.e., a custom tab item in the custom control.

remarks.para: This custom is meant to be used in close association with the custom control. The TabContainer is a dedicated for hosting tabs in the viewing area of a clinical application. The functionality and the visualization of a TabContainer differs from that of a regular TabControl.

Tab container items, which host viewers or viewing arrangements, typically have a Maximize/Restore toggle button as well as a Close button. The Maximize/Restore toggle button can be used to maximize a viewer or a viewing arrangement within its viewing area, and to restore the viewing area to its original tabbed layout. The Close button, on the other hand, can be used to close an individual TabContainerItem. This is similar to the Close button found on the tabs in modern web browsers such as Microsoft Edge or Google Chrome.

To support the feature that a TabContainerItem can be closed, this custom control exposes a dependency property, which can be used to determine whether the tab container item can be closed or not. If this property is set to , the tab container item cannot be closed, and its Close button is not visible.

In addition to the IsClosable property, the TabContainerItem also exposes three related properties , , and , which together can be used to define the command that is executed when the Close button is clicked. These properties allow application builders to attach custom business logic to the handling of the Close button click events.

The TabContainerItem expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_MaximizeRestoreButton The Maximize/Restore toggle button. Must be a .
PART_CloseButton The Close button. Must be a .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.TextExtension
member.summary: Helper class to extend the behavior to and controls.
member.remarks:
This class extends the behavior of the and controls. This class provides an attached dependency property ShowToolTipWhenTrimmed that can be used to let TextBlock and AccessText instances automatically show a when the text that is displayed by these controls does not fit, and is trimmed (truncated). The content of the tooltip will be equal to the content of the TextBlock or AccessText control.
The following example shows how to define a custom for the standard control that trims its content by using the ellipsis character, and that automatically shows a when the content is trimmed.
<Style x:Key="TextBlockStyle" TargetType="{x:Type TextBlock}"> <Setter Property="TextTrimming" Value="CharacterEllipsis"/> <Setter Property="ptc:TextExtension.ShowToolTipWhenTrimmed" Value="True"/> </Style>

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ToolBarContainer.MouseOffDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance to the nearest edge of the ToolBarContainer from the point at which the mouse is considered to be 'off' the ToolBarContainer.

remarks.para: When the ToolBarContainer is pinned, and when the mouse is off the ToolBarContainer, the opacity of the internal toolbar tray will be equal to the . When the mouse is directly over the toolbar, the opacity will be 1 and in between, the opacity increases gradually when the mouse approaches the toolbar.

When the ToolBarContainer is not pinned, the same holds, except that the mouse off opacity is considered to be 0. So the fading in and fading out is between opacity 0 and 1 instead of between MouseOffOpacity and 1.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.XrayMovieBar
member.summary: Custom control that provides basic movie and navigation functionality that is suitable for X-ray data.

remarks.para:
The XrayMovieBar expects various named template parts to be defined in its control template. These template parts are:
PART_MainContainer The main container that hosts the movie bar. This template part captures and handles and events for the movie bar.
PART_Ellipse An that serves as a hint for users to access the movie bar functionality in case the movie bar is "hidden". The ellipse is a subtle visual hint or indication that the movie bar is there, and hovering over it will reveal the full movie bar functionality.
PART_FrameRateContainer The container for the frame rate functionality of the movie bar. This template part captures and handles and events for the frame rate functionality of the movie bar.
PART_FrameRateSlider A that allows the user to change the frame rate at which the movie is played.
PART_PlayPauseButton A that allows the user to toggle between playing and pausing the movie.
PART_RecommendedFrameRateThumb A that represents a visual indication of the recommended frame rate for a given set of images.
PART_MovieBarHitTester A transparent that is used as hit-tester when the movie bar is in unpinned state.
PART_LegsBackground
PART_LeftLegContent Container on the movie bar with content placed on the left side of the movie bar.
PART_Core Container on the movie bar with content placed in the middle of the movie bar.
PART_OverflowButton The movie bar overflow button. Clicking this button will open the overflow popup panel, which hosts all the controls that do not fit on the movie bar itself.
PART_Pin The movie bar pin button. If the movie bar is pinned, the auto-hide behavior is disabled. See the dependency property.
PART_LeftCoreContent
The container for the PART_PreviousImageButton and PART_PreviousSeriesButton.
PART_PreviousImageButton
The previous image button. Clicking this will navigate to the previous image.
PART_PreviousSeriesButton
The previous series button. Clicking this will navigate to the previous series.
PART_StudyOverviewButton
The study overview button. Clicking this will show all images in the study.
PART_SeriesOverviewButton
The series overview button. Clicking this will show an overview of the series.
PART_RightCoreContent
The container for the PART_NextImageButton and PART_NextSeriesButton.
PART_NextImageButton
The next image button. Clicking this will navigate to the next image in the movie.
PART_NextSeriesButton
The next series button. Clicking this will navigate to the next series.
PART_StudyCycleButton
The cycle study button. Clicking this will make the movie cycle over the series.
PART_FrameRateIndexSlider
The frame rate index slider. Clicking the button shows a slider that can change the frame rate of the movie.

The user can navigate through the available frame rate values. These are either determined by the and properties, which allow for a continuous range of frame rate values; or they are determined by explicitly setting a collection of available frame rate values using the property, which allows the application builder to define a fixed set of discrete frame rate values.

Navigation through the frame rate values is either cyclic, or it respects the boundaries set by the minimum and maximum frame rate values. This latter mode is the default, as it corresponds most naturally to the user's expectations of this behavior. The default behavior can be changed by setting the value of the property to .

This class provides basic movie functionality that is not specialized for any modality or data type. If you need specific movie functionality for your modality, or for your type of clinical data, you can implement a dedicated movie bar that derives from this basic movie bar, or you can implement one from scratch.

The WPF Presentation Toolkit provides a number of dedicated, specialized movie bars:
MRMovieBar Movie bar specialized for MR data sets.
Movie bar specialized for X-ray data sets (this class).

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.XrayMovieBar.HasCycleStudy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the movie bar has a user interface to switch the "Cycle Study" mode on or off. In the "Cycle Study" mode, the movie bar automatically cycles through all the movies (i.e., runs) that are part of the same study.

remarks.para: Use this property to configure whether the movie bar exposes a user interface (typically, a toggle button) to switch the "Cycle Study" mode on or off. This property should not be confused with the property, which is used to determine whether the "Cycle Study" mode is currently active.
By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.XrayMovieBar.HasOverviewNavigation
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the movie bar has a user interface to navigate through an overview, which can be either a series overview, an exam overview, or a study overview.

remarks.para: Typically, the movie bar will show buttons to navigate to the next and previous page of the currently active overview (series, exam, or study) if this property is set to . However, it is the responsibility of the movie bar style to visualize this state in an appropriate way.
The default value is .
A viewer that uses a scroll bar for browsing in overview mode, will typically set this property to .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.BooleanToValueConverter
member.summary: Converts a Boolean to a predefined value if or a different predefined value if .

remarks.para: This BooleanToValueConverter can be used to set a generic value if true or a different value if false. For example, a property such as visibility can be set to if the Boolean value is , or if the Boolean value is .

member.example:
The following example shows how an BooleanToValueConverter can be used to change the visibility of a control depending on whether or not it is enabled.
<Grid.Resources> <pt:BooleanToValueConverter x:Key="BooleanToValueConverter" FalseValue="{x:Static Visibility.Hidden}" TrueValue="{x:Static Visibility.Visible}"/> </Grid.Resources> <Button Visibility="{Binding IsEnabled, Source={RelativeSource Self}, Converter={StaticResource BooleanToValueConverter}}"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CaseConverter
member.summary: Represents an that converts the casing of the input string.

remarks.para: The CaseConverter class can be used to convert input strings into upper or lower case according to the property. Setting is a shortcut for setting both and . It is therefore possible to specify that the source and target properties be converted to different casings.
The code is based on Kent Boogaart's WPF Converters, V1.3.0.0. See .

member.example:
The following example shows how a CaseConverter can be used to convert a bound value to upper-case. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<Label x:Name="upperCaseLabel" Content="{Binding Name, Converter={ptc:CaseConverter Upper}}"/>

The following example shows how a CaseConverter can be used to convert a bound value to upper-case, but display it in lower-case. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<Label x:Name="lowerCaseLabel" Content="{Binding Name, Converter={CaseConverter SourceCasing=Upper, TargetCasing=Lower} }"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CompareConverter
member.summary: A custom converter that compares the input value to the . The types of comparison are defined by the values of the enumeration.

remarks.para: This converter can compare two instances with each other. The original value has to be strongly typed and has to have the same type as the input value, otherwise an exception will be thrown.

This converter has a limitation that only one of the values to be compared can be passed into the method. The other value to be compared must be assigned as a constant to the property. Note that this cannot be done using a in XAML. So, the values that is passed to the OriginalValue must always be a constant. If you need to pass two values using a Binding for each value, you cannot use this converter. Instead, you will need to use the .

member.example:
The following example shows how to use the CompareConverter to check if a value is less than or equal to 1. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<Binding Path="Count" ConverterParameter="{x:Static ptc:ComparisonType.LessThanOrEqual}" RelativeSource="{RelativeSource Self}"> <Binding.Converter> <ptc:CompareConverter> <ptc:CompareConverter.OriginalValue> <sys:Int32>1</sys:Int32> </ptc:CompareConverter.OriginalValue> </ptc:CompareConverter> </Binding.Converter> </Binding>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CompareConverter.Convert(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Attempts to compare the given value to the .
member.param: The value to compare with the .
The type of the binding target property.
The parameter is used to specify the type of comparison . If it is not set explicitly, is used.
The culture to use in the converter.
member.returns: , when the specified value can be compared to the , and the result of the comparison is true; , when the specified value can be compared to the , and the result of the comparison is false; , when the specified value cannot be compared to the (for example, because the two values are not of the same type, or do not implement ).

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CompareConverter.ConvertBack(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts a value.
member.remarks: Not implemented as it is not required.
member.param: The value to convert.
The type to convert to.
The converter parameter to use.
The culture to use in the converter.
member.exception: Thrown because converting back is currently not implemented (it is not required).

member.summary: Gets or sets the original value, which is the value to compare with.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.CompareMultiValueConverter
member.summary: A custom multi-value converter that compares two input values. The types of comparison are defined by the values of the enumeration.

remarks.para: This converter can compare two instances with each other. Both input values can be passed to the method, making this converter suitable to be used in a where each of the input values is the subject of a .

member.example:
The following example shows how to use the CompareConverter to check if the and values are equal to each other, which is a way to check whether the scrollable content is scrolled all the way down. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<MultiBinding Converter="{ptc:CompareMultiValueConverter}" ConverterParameter="{x:Static ptc:ComparisonType.Equal}"> <Binding Path="VerticalOffset" RelativeSource="{RelativeSource Self}"/> <Binding Path="ScrollableHeight" RelativeSource="{RelativeSource Self}"/> </MultiBinding>

The type of the binding target property.
The parameter is used to specify the type of comparison . If it is not set explicitly, is used.
The culture to use in the converter.
member.returns: , when the (first two) specified values can be compared, and the result of the comparison is true; , when the (first two) specified values can be compared, and the result of the comparison is false; , when the (first two) specified values cannot be compared (for example, because the two values are not of the same type, or do not implement ).

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DateConverter.DefaultCulture
member.summary: Gets or sets the default culture to be used in presentation toolkit components and other users of this converter which abides by the user specified default.
member.remarks:
By default, is used for formatting dates; however, to provide a way to change the default in the presentation toolkit components and other users of this converter, this property can be used to explicitly override the default.
Unless there is a good reason to do so, this should not be changed from its default value.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DivideConverter
member.summary: A custom converter that can be used to divide a value (the dividend or numerator) by another value (the divisor or denominator).

remarks.para: The DivideConverter class can be used to convert a double value to another double value which is the result of dividing the input double value by a specified denominator. The input double value is provided as the value argument to the method. The denominator is set via the property.

For the time being, this converter only handles double values. This means that it only accepts double input values, and the result of the conversion will also be a double, or if the division cannot be performed.

member.example:
The following example shows how the can be used. Here, the converter is used to calculate the center of the grid.
<Style.Resources> <ptc:DivideConverter x:Key="DivideConverter" Denominator="-2"/> </Style.Resources>
<Grid.RenderTransform> <TransformGroup> <TranslateTransform X="{ Binding Path=ActualWidth, Converter={StaticResource DivideConverter}, RelativeSource={RelativeSource Self} }" Y="{ Binding Path=ActualHeight, Converter={StaticResource DivideConverter}, RelativeSource={RelativeSource Self} }" /> </TransformGroup> </Grid.RenderTransform>

member.param: The value to divide, i.e., the numerator.
The type of the binding target property.
The is not used.
The culture is not used.
member.returns: The result of the division; or if the division cannot be performed. In case of a division by zero, this conversion method returns , in accordance with .

member.param: The value to convert.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleToDurationConverter
member.summary: Converts a double value which represents a duration in milliseconds to a value.
member.remarks: This converter converts a value in milliseconds to a duration. The value is assumed to be a double and positive.
member.example:
The following example shows how the can be used. Here, the converter is used to bind the animation speed of an expanding rectangle to the width of another element.
<Rectangle x:Name="targetRectangle Width=400/> <Rectangle x:Name="rectangle" Width="0"> <Rectangle.Triggers> <EventTrigger RoutedEvent="Rectangle.Loaded"> <BeginStoryboard> <Storyboard TargetName="rectangle" RepeatBehavior="Forever"> <DoubleAnimation Storyboard.TargetProperty="Width" From="0" To="{Binding ActualWidth, ElementName=targetRectangle}" Duration="{ Binding ActualWidth, ElementName=targetRectangle, Converter={ptc:DoubleToDurationConverter}}"/> </Storyboard> </BeginStoryboard> </EventTrigger> </Rectangle.Triggers> </Rectangle>

The culture to use in the converter (ignored).

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.EnumToBooleanConverter
member.summary: Converts enumeration values to Boolean.
member.remarks: This converter can be used to convert an enumeration value to a Boolean. This can be used, for example, to determine if a user interface should element be enabled, checked, visible, etc., depending on the value of an enumeration type that is bound to the user interface element. The enumeration value to convert is provided as the value argument of the Convert method, and the enumeration value to compare with is provided as the parameter argument of the Convert method. The result is if and only if the two enumeration values are equal.
member.example:
The following example shows how a EnumToBooleanConverter can be used to convert an enumeration value to a Boolean. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<CheckBox IsChecked="{Binding SomeEnumProperty, Converter={ptc:EnumToBooleanConverter}}"/>

member.returns: , if is equal to . , if is not equal to . , if is . , if is not an enumeration value.
