member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ExpressionConverter
member.summary: Converts a simple mathematical expression to an integer or a double value (depending on whether the result of calculating the mathematical expression can be expressed as an integer, or needs to be expressed as a double).

remarks.para: This ExpressionConverter can be used to implement simple mathematical expressions in XAML. It does so by accepting an input value, which should be a positive integer (or 0), and a simple string representation of the mathematical operation that we want to apply to this input value. For example, with an input value of 10, and a mathematical operation of "@VALUE+5", the output of the converter would be 10 + 5 = 15. Likewise, an input value of 100 and a mathematical operation of "@VALUE/4" would yield 100 / 4 = 25.
This simple expression converter currently supports the operators "+", "-", "*", "/", "%", and the grouping operators "(" and ")".

member.example:
The following example shows how an ExpressionConverter can be used to carry out a mathematical equation on a bound value. Operator order is parenthesis first, then Left-To-Right (no operator precedence). Use @VALUE in your mathEquation as a substitute for bound value.
<TextBox x:Name="headerTextBox" Width="{Binding ElementName=contentPresenter, Path=ActualWidth, Converter={ptc:ExpressionConverter}, ConverterParameter=@VALUE-30}"

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ExpressionConverter.Convert(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts the specified value by applying the specified mathematical expression to it.
member.param: The specified element value in the expression. This should be a positive integer, or 0.
The type of the binding target property(currently ignored).
The value to compare with.
The culture to use in the converter (currently ignored).
member.returns: The calculated value of the expression, or if the string to be evaluated is not valid.
member.exception: Thrown when a non-numeric, an operator or brackets are found in the string.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.HasAncestorConverter
member.summary: Tries to find whether or not a control has an ancestor of a certain type.

remarks.para: This HasAncestorConverter can be used to detect wheter or not a control has a parent of a certain type in either its logical or visual tree.

member.example:
The following example shows how an HasAncestorConverter can be used to change the foreground of a control depending on whether it is hosted in a toolbar. Note that it only searches for this parent once, on the initialization of the control. Therefore, this method should only be used if the condition does not change during runtime.
<DataTrigger Binding="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Self}, Converter={ptc:HasAncestorConverter}, ConverterParameter={x:Type ToolBar}}" Value="True"> <Setter Property = "Foreground" Value="Red"/> </DataTrigger>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.IconIdConverter
member.summary: Converts an Experience Identity icon ID to its corresponding sDLS icon ID.
member.remarks: Most of the sDLS icon IDs match their Experience Identity counterparts. There are, however, a number of sDLS icon IDs that are different from the corresponding Experience Identity icon IDs. This converter allows the caller to resolve these mismatches by always returning the sDLS icon ID that matches the specified Experience Identity icon ID.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MinMaxStepToDashConverter
member.summary: A custom, multi-value converter which takes a number of parameters, and converts those values to a DoubleCollection, indicating an on-off pattern for the pen. This value converter calculates the pattern on the basis of the number of steps between a min and a max: for each step, exactly one dash is generated. Because a WPF StrokeDashArray (for which this value converter can be used) multiplies the length of the dashes by the stroke thickness, this value converter compensates for this effect by dividing by the same thickness.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MinMaxStepToDashConverter.Convert(System.Object[],System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts the specified values to a value.
member.param:
The value produced by the binding source. It should be a list of double values, with a length of 6:
min The minimum value of the control
max The maximum value of the control
steps
The step size value. The number of steps/drawn dashes is (max-min)/step.
length The length of the control (dip).
gapLength The length of the gap between the dashes (dip).
strokeThickness The stroke thickness (dip), needed for the compensation.
The type of the binding target property (ignored).
The converter parameter to use (ignored).
The culture to use in the converter (ignored).
member.returns: A DoubleCollection, with a length equal to 2 times the number of steps. It indicates an on-off pattern: turn on the pen for x pixels, turn off the pen for y pixels etc. In case the input does not conform to the expectations, the method will return in case the value parameter does not meet the specifications.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.MinMaxStepToDashConverter.CreateDoubleDashCollection(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a collection of doubles which represent the dashed line.
member.param: The dash count.
The dash length in pixels.
The gap length in pixels.
The stroke thickness.

member.example:

<Slider> <Slider.Maximum> <Binding Path="SliderValue" ElementName="sliderValueSelector" Converter="{ptc:OffsetConverter}"> <Binding.ConverterParameter> <sys:Int32>-1</sys:Int32> </Binding.ConverterParameter> </Binding> </Slider.Maximum> </Slider>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PairwiseOrConverter
member.summary: Converts an array of Booleans to a single Boolean value, which equals the disjunction of the conjunction of successive pairs in the array. The conversion in the other direction is not supported.
member.remarks: The PairwiseOrConverter class can be used to check if among a group of Boolean pairs, there exists a pair for which both its Boolean values are .

example.para: The following example shows how the can be used to set the IsChecked property of a . For the SplitToggleButton to be checked one of the SplitButtonItems needs to be both checked and selected. The SplitToggleButtonBehavior ensures that the converter is evaluated on every click of the button.
This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
example.code: <ptc:SplitToggleButton x:Name="exampleSplitToggleButton" Style="{DynamicResource SplitToggleButtonStyle}" ptc:SplitToggleButtonBehavior.UpdateTargetOnClick="True"> <ptc:SplitToggleButton.IsChecked> <MultiBinding Converter="{ptc:PairwiseOrConverter}" Mode="OneWay"> <Binding ElementName="splitButtonItem1" Path="DataContext.IsChecked"/> <Binding ElementName="splitButtonItem1" Path="IsSelected"/> <Binding ElementName="splitButtonItem2" Path="DataContext.IsChecked"/> <Binding ElementName="splitButtonItem2" Path="IsSelected"/> </MultiBinding> </ptc:SplitToggleButton.IsChecked> <ptc:SplitButtonItem x:Name="splitButtonItem1" DataContext="{Binding CurrentTask.AnnotationsTool.LineAnnotationCommand}"> </ptc:SplitButtonItem> <ptc:SplitButtonItem x:Name="splitButtonItem2" DataContext="{Binding CurrentTask.AnnotationsTool.CircleROIAnnotationCommand}"> </ptc:SplitButtonItem> </ptc:SplitToggleButton>

member.returns: , if one of the pairs of the array holds true for both its values; , otherwise.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter
member.summary: Represents an that converts a to its corresponding icon (image).
member.remarks: This converter can be used in combination with its markup extension, which makes it easy to create an instance of this converter in XAML code.
member.example:
The following example shows how to use the PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter with the PictorialDataTypeToIconConverterExtension inside a binding. By default, the icon that will be produced by the converter is an Experience Identity icon.
<Image Source="{Binding SomePictorialDataTypeValue, Converter={pt:PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter} }"/>

The following example shows how to use the PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter with the PictorialDataTypeToIconConverterExtension inside a binding to produce an icon for the sDLS Very Dark Gray theme.
<Image Source="{Binding SomePictorialDataTypeValue, Converter={pt:PictorialDataTypeToIconConverter}, ConverterParameter={x:Static pt:PresentationTheme.DesignLanguageSystemVeryDarkGray} }"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverter
member.summary: A value converter that converts a to an icon that represents this value in the user interface.
member.remarks: This converter can be used in combination with its markup extension, which makes it easy to create an instance of this converter in XAML code.
member.example:
The following example shows how to use the PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverter with the PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverterExtension inside a binding:
<Image Source="{Binding SomePictorialPrintStatusValue, Converter={pt:PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverter} }"/>

The following example shows how to use the PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverter with the PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverterExtension inside a binding to produce an icon for the sDLS Very Dark Gray theme.
<Image Source="{Binding SomePictorialMediaStatusValue, Converter={pt:PictorialPrintStatusToIconConverter}, ConverterParameter={x:Static pt:PresentationTheme.DesignLanguageSystemVeryDarkGray} }"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.RadiansToDegreesConverter
member.summary: Converts radians to degrees (and vice versa).
member.remarks: This converter converts radians to degrees, and vice versa. The converter parameter can be used to specify whether the conversion must be performed modulo 360 (2). If so, the converted value lies in the range [0..360) or [0..2). If not, converted values larger than 360 (2) are possible.
member.example:
The following example shows how a RadiansToDegreesConverter can be used to convert radians to degrees. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<Label Content="{Binding AngleInRadians, Converter={ptc:RadiansToDegreesConverter}}"/>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.RadiansToDegreesConverter.Convert(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts a value from radians to degrees.
member.param: The value (in radians) to convert. Should be a double.
The type of the conversion result.

Flag indicating whether the conversion should be performed modulo 360 (degrees). If this parameter is , the converted value lies in the range [0, 360), i.e., from 0 degrees up to, but not including, 360 degrees. If this parameter is , the converted value lies in the range [0, ...), i.e., from 0 degrees upward.
The culture to use in the converter.
member.returns: The value in degrees, converted from the value in radians; or if the value is not a double.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.RadiansToDegreesConverter.ConvertBack(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts a value from degrees to radians.
member.param: The value (in degrees) to convert. Should be a double.
The type of the conversion result.

Flag indicating whether the conversion should be performed modulo 360 (degrees). If this parameter is , the converted value lies in the range [0, 2), i.e., from 0 up to, but not including, 2. If this parameter is , the converted value lies in the range [0, ...), i.e., from 0 upward.
The culture to use in the converter.
member.returns: The value in radians, converted from the value in degrees. or if the value is not a double.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.TimeConverter
member.summary: Converts or values to strings that can be presented in the user interface.
member.remarks: This converter is only concerned with converting times. If you want to convert dates, you should use its sibling, the .
member.example:
The following example shows how a TimeConverter to convert the DateTime of the custom control. The converter uses the harmonized culture, and passes "False" to the ConverterParameter property in order to have the time displayed in hours and minutes only (no seconds).
<TextBlock.Text> <Binding Path="DateTime" RelativeSource="{RelativeSource AncestorType={x:Type ptc:Clock}}" Converter="{StaticResource TimeConverter}" ConverterParameter="False" ConverterCulture="{x:Static ptc:TimeConverter.HarmonizedCulture}"> </Binding> </TextBlock.Text>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.TimeConverter.Convert(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts the specified value, which should represent a or a , to a string representation which is suitable for display.
member.remarks:
The specified value should be converted to a string representation using the "International Settings" time format as defined by UI Harmonization. The and the are ignored.
Applications must explicitly set the property to the culture to be used. This must be or an alternative format if deviation from the Standard is legitimized.
member.param: The value produced by the binding source.
The type of the binding target property.

The converter parameter. This is used to determine whether the conversion should use the "HH:mm:ss" format, or the "HH:mm" format. The format including seconds is used if this converter parameter can be parsed as a Boolean with the value . The format without seconds is used if this converter parameter can be parsed as a Boolean with the value .
The culture to use in the converter.
member.returns: The converted value, if the value is indeed a or a ; or the (localized) string "Unknown", otherwise, to indicate that the specified value does not represent a valid date/time.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.TreeViewIndentationConverter
member.summary: Represents an that calculates the indentation of a tree view item.
member.remarks: In a , each has an indentation depending on its nesting level in the tree view. This converter can be used to calculate the indentation of a tree view item in device-independent units [px]. The assumption is that all nesting levels use the same unit of indentation - for example, each nesting level adds an indentation of 12px with respect to the previous nesting level. This "unit of indentation" can be communicated to the converter via the property.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ValueConverterGroup
member.summary: A custom value converter that takes a list of converter and applies them one after the other in the order specified by the list.

remarks.para: Sometimes, the need arises to apply multiple value converters after one another. This is called "chaining", "piping", or "cascading" of converters. This custom ValueConverterGroup takes care of this need. It accepts an ordered list of value converters, where the output of any particular value converter serves as the input for the next value converter in the list. It then applies these value converters in the order that is specified by the list.

This converter does not follow the common pattern of having a associated with it. The reason is that a markup extension is introduced such that it is not necessary to define a converter as a static resource in a XAML file every time we need it. However, defining this particular converter as a static resource is inevitable because we need to specify the list of child converters. So, there is no way around defining the converter as a static resource (see the example below), and therefore a markup extension does not make much sense.
This converter was inspired by the work of Gareth Evans and others which you can find in this StackOverflow article on chaining value converters.

member.example: The following example illustrates how to convert a (fictional) property value of type FooEnum to a value using the ValueConverterGroup to define a cascade of and . First, we need to set up the cascading value converter group as a static resource. As you can see, the ValueConverterGroup takes an ordered list of child converters. Second, we use the resulting cascading converter to accept a property value of type FooEnum. This value is first converted to a Boolean by the EnumToBooleanConverter, which returns if and only if the property value matches the expected enum value defined as the converter parameter. The Boolean that is produced in this way is picked up by the second converter, which converts it to a Visibility value.
member.code: <pt:ValueConverterGroup x:Key="EnumToVisibilityConverter"> <pt:EnumToBooleanConverter/> <BooleanToVisibilityConverter/> </pt:ValueConverterGroup> ... <Button x:Name="button" Visibility="{Binding FooEnumProperty, Converter={StaticResource EnumToVisibilityConverter}, ConverterParameter={x:Static FooEnum.BarValue} }"/>
member.seealso: Is there a way to chain multiple value converters in XAML?

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ValueConverterGroup.Convert(System.Object,System.Type,System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts a value.
member.remarks: It is assumed that the list of child converters is valid, in the sense that the output value of any child converter matches the expected input value of the next converter in the list. The validity of the chain of child converters is not checked or enforced by this method, as it is considered to be a programming error if this condition is not met.
member.param: The value produced by the binding source. This value should match the expected type of the value of the first converter in the list of child converters.
The type of the binding target property.
The converter parameter to use.
The culture to use in the converter.
member.returns: The value that is the result of applying the list of child converters of this value converter group one after the other in the order that is specified by the list. The return value matches the return type of the last converter in the list of child converters.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ValueToBracketedValueConverter
member.summary: Converts a value to a value between brackets, and prefixed with a space, so that it can be appended to a string.

remarks.para: The Experience Identity defines that, if the row details of a list are expanded, the operations (i.e., applications) shown on the buttons in the row details are appended with the number of selected rows on which they act. For example, if two rows are selected, and a "View" operation is defined, then the row details should show "View (2)", to indicate that two items can be viewed. If only one item is selected, the display of the operation is kept simple, and instead of "View (1)" we simply show "View".

This converter addresses this display problem in a generic way. It assumes that the string representing the operation ("View", "Print", "Report", etc.) is available and needs to be appended with the number of selected items, between brackets. This converter accepts the value to put between brackets as the value parameter of the method. It accepts the opening bracket to use as the converter parameter of the Convert method. This converter finds the matching closing bracket, provided that the opening bracket is one of { "(", "[", "{", "<", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "". The set of accepted opening brackets includes brackets used in East-Asian languages, including full-width versions of the normal (round) bracket, the square bracket, and the curly bracket.
This converter works by passing the selected items count as value to the method, and the opening bracket as parameter.

member.example:
The following example shows how a ValueToBracketedValueConverter can be used to convert a value to a bracketed value. This example uses the more convenient way of addressing the converter in XAML by making use of the .
<Label Content="{ Binding SomeStringProperty, Converter={ptc:ValueToBracketedValueConverter}, ConverterParameter='(' }"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ValueToBooleanConverter
member.summary: Tries to convert a generic value to a Boolean. The value is compared with a parameter to determine wheter true or false should returned. value if false.

remarks.para: This ValueToBooleanConverter can be used to compare a generic value with set values to determine whether true or false should be returned. For example, this can be used to determine whether a control is visible, by setting the Visibility of a control and setting the true value to Visibility.Visible and the false value to Visibility.Hidden.
This ValueToBooleanConverter uses the BooleanToValueConverter, so it behaves in the exact same way, but in reverse.

member.example:
The following example shows how an ValueToBooleanConverter can be used to disable a control based on whether or not a different control is visible.
<Grid.Resources> <pt:ValueToBooleanConverter x:Key="VisibilityToBooleanConverter" TrueValue="{x:Static Visibility.Visible}" FalseValue="{x:Static Visibility.Hidden}"/> </Grid.Resources> <Button x:Name="button1" IsEnabled="{Binding=Visibility, ElementName="button2", Converter={StaticResource VisibilityToBooleanConverter}}"/> <Button x:Name="button2" Visibility="Visible"/>

The following shows how to use the ValueToBooleanConverterExtension inside a binding to hide a button when a togglebutton is checked:
<Button Visibility="{Binding IsChecked, ElementName=toggleButton, Converter={pt:ValueToBooleanConverter TrueValue={x:Static Visibility.Hidden}, FalseValue ={x:Static Visibility.Visible}}}"/> <ToggleButton x:Name="toggleButton"/>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.DlsBehavior
member.summary: Exposes attached behavior that is relevant for multiple sDLS controls, but is not relevant for Experience Identity controls.

remarks.para: sDLS offers a richer user experience than Experience Identity. This means that some behaviors or visual aspects are relevant for sDLS controls, but not for their Experience Identity counterparts. This attached behavior class captures that.

First of all, this class provides an attached property BackgroundType, which can be used to instruct a according to what it should visualize itself. Dependending on the value of this property, the UI element may need to visualize itself differently, in conformance with the sDLS visual specifications. In particular, this attached property dictates what background the UI element should use. This is typically implemented by defining a in the UI element's style which responds to the value of this attached property.

sDLS also dictates that, sometimes, adjacent controls should be separated by a . For example, two adjacent controls on a may need to be separated by a separator under certain circumstances. This behavior can be governed by the ShowSeparator attached property provided by this class.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.PixelShaderBehavior
member.summary: Exposes behavior to enable or disable the pixel shader for sDLS icons.

remarks.para: Most sDLS icons of the first generation are single color icons that do not have an intrinsic color. Rather, the color of the sDLS icon is determined by its context - the control it is used in, the state of the control, whether the mouse hovers over the control, etc. All of these different color varieties are achieved by hooking up a pixel shader that recolors the icon according to its context of use.

It is not always desirable to pass an icon image through the pixel shader to have it recolored. Some sDLS icons, for example, are true multicolor icons instead of single color icons without a "real" color. Passing these multicolor icons through the pixel shader might cause unwanted recoloring (depending on how smart the pixel shader implementation is). In order to prevent the pixel shader from doing its work, this attached behavior class provides a dependency property to enable or disable the pixel shader.

Typically, the IsPixelShaderEnabled property is set on a UI element that knows how to handle it. This can be a , a , or a . When set to , the sDLS style for the UI element should make sure that the pixel shader is not applied.

member.example:
The following example shows how to disable the pixel shader for a that shows a multicolor icon which does not need to be recolored by the pixel shader.
<MenuItem x:Name="unshadedMenuItem" Header="Menu item with disabled pixel shader" dls:PixelShaderBehavior.IsPixelShaderEnabled="False"> <MenuItem.Icon> <Image Source="{StaticResource DLS_SomeMulticolor_RefIcon}"/> </MenuItem.Icon> </MenuItem>

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType
member.summary: Enumeration defining the different colors for the background of a control.
member.remarks: The background of a control depends on the zone the control is in. This zone can be a navigation zone or a content zone. Within a zone, different levels can be used to show contrast between different controls within a zone. Note that not every control can exist within every zone, so not all of these options may apply.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.Default
member.summary: Default: Represents the default background of a control.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.NavigationPrimary
member.summary: NavigationPrimary: Represents the background color for a control in a navigation zone at a primary (high) level.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.NavigationSecondary
member.summary: NavigationSecondary: Represents the background color for a control in a navigation zone at a secondary (low) level.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.ContentPrimary
member.summary: ContentPrimary: Represents the background color for a control in a content zone at a primary (high) level.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.ContentSecondary
member.summary: ContentSecondary: Represents the background color for a control in a content zone at a secondary (medium) level.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.ContentTertiary
member.summary: ContentTertiary: Represents the background color for a control in a content zone at a tertiary (low) level.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.BackgroundType.Transparent
member.summary: Transparent: Represents the background of a control that should use the color of the control below it.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonType
member.summary: Enumeration defining the style types of buttons

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonType.Secondary
member.summary: Secondary Button.
member.remarks: The secondary button is a rectangular button with lower visual recognition. Use a secondary button for actions that require less attention. More than one secondary button can be used within each layout area of the user interface.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonType.Accent
member.summary: Accent Button.
member.remarks: The accent button is a button with the highest visual recognition.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonType.Primary
member.summary: Primary Button.
member.remarks: The primary button is a rectangular button with high visual recognition. It stands out and can be used to direct attention to an important action. For example, saving a document. We recommend using one primary button per layout area of the user interface.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonType.Quiet
member.summary: Quiet Button.
member.remarks: The quiet button is a button without a visible background. This button demands the lowest visual recognition. It can be used in-line and in contexts where rectangular buttons require too much visual attention. Quiet buttons can also be combined with primary and secondary buttons.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonListPositionType
member.summary: Enumeration defining the different position options for buttons in a button list.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonListPositionType.Single
member.summary: Single: Represents a button in a list with only one single button.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonListPositionType.First
member.summary: First: Represents the first button in a button list.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonListPositionType.InBetween
member.summary: InBetween: Represents the buttons between the first and the last button in a button list.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Dls.ButtonListPositionType.Last
member.summary: First: Represents the last button in a button list.

summary.para: The WPF Presentation Toolkit is a collection of WPF controls, components, utilities, and styles for creating WPF applications that conform to the Experience Identity as defined by the User Interface Competence Center (UICC).

The WPF Presentation Toolkit provides Experience Identity styles for many out-of-the-box WPF controls. Additionally, it also provides a comprehensive collection of custom controls that are catered to the medical domain. The WPF Presentation Toolkit is highly suited to build clinical applications that reside on the traditional Microsoft desktop.

The WPF Presentation Toolkit is part of UADE, but it does not require any other UADE components. This means that you can build WPF applications that meet the Experience Identity guidelines using only the WPF Presentation Toolkit. Of course, using the WPF Presentation Toolkit alongside other UADE components is also possible.
The WPF Presentation Toolkit supports the Experience Identity 1.1 (EI 1.1).

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.BooleanToValueConverterExtension
member.summary: Implements a markup extension that allows instances of to be easily created.

remarks.para: This markup extension allows an instance of to be easily created inline in a XAML binding. See the example below.

member.example:
The following shows how to use the BooleanToValueConverter inside a binding to hide a button when a togglebutton is checked:

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ConverterMarkupExtension`1
member.summary: A generic markup extension for converters.

remarks.para: This class provides a generic way to construct markup extensions for converters. This is only relevant if your converter does not define any additional properties. If your converter does define additional properties, you are probably better off constructing your extension by deriving directly from .
To use this generic class, make sure that your converter is a class that has a default constructor, and that it implements the interface.
There is also a version of this class for single-value converters, see .

member.example:
The following shows how to use this class to create a markup extension for the (fictional) FooConverter. Strictly speaking, it is not necessary to define the , but it does make the purpose of the extension more clear.
[MarkupExtensionReturnType(typeof(FooConverter))] public sealed class FooConverterExtension : ConverterMarkupExtension<FooConverter>

member.summary: Provides an instance of the converter that this class is an extension for.

member.returns: The singleton instance of the converter that this class is an extension for.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScalableIconExtension
member.summary: Markup extension which allows for selecting the image (bitmap) at the requested size from a Windows icon (a .ico file).

remarks.para: WPF does not properly support the different sizes stored in a Windows icon out-of-the-box. This makes it possible to specify the required width and height (in pixels) at which an icon needs to be rendered. The implementation of this markup extension extracts the bitmap image which best matches the required width and height from the icon. The resulting bitmap image is returned as an .

A limitation of this markup extension is that WPF specifies pixels in device-independent units, whereas a Windows icon specifies pixels in device-dependent units. Please keep in mind that the one device-independent pixel in WPF corresponds to 1/96th of an inch - in other words, device-independent pixels exactly correspond to Windows icon pixels only on a 96 dpi screen. The requested size is specified on this markup extension in device-dependent pixels, because this corresponds to the pixel units in the Windows icon (.ico) file. It only corresponds to WPF device-independent pixels on a 96 dpi screen.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScalableIconExtension.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScalableIconExtension.#ctor(System.Uri)
member.summary: Creates a new instance for the specified icon.
member.param: An URI specifying the icon that is scaled by this markup extension.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScalableIconExtension.#ctor(System.Uri,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance for the specified icon.
member.param: An URI specifying the icon that is scaled by this markup extension.
The requested width (in pixels) for the specified icon.
The requested height (in pixels) for the specified icon.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.ScalableIconExtension.ProvideValue(System.IServiceProvider)
member.summary: Provides an which best matches the and for the specified .
member.remarks: This method selects the (bitmap) image which best matches the requested size from an icon which possibly holds images at different sizes. If an exact match exists, the corresponding image is returned. If no exact match exists, the best matching image is returned, where "best matching" is defined as the smallest image that is larger than the requested size. This allows for downscaling of the returned image to the requested size, which generally gives better results than upscaling.
member.param: The service provider.
member.exception: Thrown if the is . Also thrown if the that needs to be scaled is not defined, or cannot be resolved, or if the requested height cannot be determined, or if the target of this markup extension is not an . Exceptions that are raised by streaming the specified icon are rethrown as with the inner exception set to the original exception.
member.returns: An which is scaled to the requested width and height (in device-dependent pixels).

member.summary: Gets or sets the URI specifying the icon that is scaled by this markup extension.
member.remarks: Failure to provide a value for this property will raise an when the method is called.

member.summary: Gets or sets the requested width (in pixels) for the icon that is scaled by this markup extension.
member.remarks: Providing a value for this property is optional.

member.summary: Gets or sets the requested height (in pixels) for the icon that is scaled by this markup extension.
member.remarks: Failure to provide a value for this property will raise an when the method is called.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.CursorFactory.DlsCursorIdDictionary
member.summary: Dictionary mapping Experience Identity Cursor IDs to sDLS Cursor IDs.

remarks.para: This dictionary maps EI cursor IDs to their corresponding sDLS cursor IDs. Please note that not every EI cursor has an sDLS equivalent (yet). Also, some sDLS cursor never existed in EI. This latter category includes at least:
For the sake of completeness, this dictionary contains an entry for each sDLS cursor that has an EI equivalent. Even if the names of the sDLS and EI cursors are exactly the same.

member.summary: Converts an Experience Identity Cursor ID to an sDLS Cursor ID.
member.param: The Experience Identity Cursor ID to convert.
member.returns: The sDLS Cursor ID that corresponds to the specified Experience Identity Cursor ID, or the Experience Identity Cursor ID if no matching sDLS Cursor ID is found.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ExperienceIdentityColors
member.summary: Provides the set of predefined Experience Identity colors.

remarks.para: This static class provides a number of static properties, one for each of the predefined Experience Identity colors. This class is based on the standard WPF class, which provides access to the set of predefined WPF colors.

This class provides access to the Blue, Brown, Gray, Red, and Yellow color palettes of the Experience Identity. The semantic colors, such as the Annotation colors and the Notification colors, are not provided by this class. You can access these using the similar classes that are dedicated to this purpose, such as .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ExperienceIdentityCursors
member.summary: Provides strongly-typed access to all the Experience Identity cursors.

remarks.para: This static class provides a number of static properties, one for each of the predefined Experience Identity cursors. This class is based on the standard WPF class, which provides access to the set of predefined WPF cursors.
You can find all the Experience Identity cursors in Icons, Cursors and Symbols online database, otherwise known as Icopedia.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ColorUtility.KnownSafeAnnotationColors
member.summary: The collection of Experience Identity Safe Annotation Colors.
member.remarks: The Safe Annotation Colors are a subset of the that are safe to use in a context where color sensitivity or color blindness needs to be taken into account. The complete collection of Annotation Colors consists of colors that may not be distinguishable by color-sensitive users. The Safe Annotation Colors have been carefully selected, and tested, to be distinguishable by color-sensitive users.

Flag indicating whether the alpha channel is used or not.
member.returns: The formatted color name. For example, if the color name is "#FF00BF8430", then the formatted color name is the same if the alpha channel is used, and "#00BF8430" if the alpha channel is not used.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.HsvColor
member.summary: Represents a color according to the Hue-Saturation-Value color model.
member.remarks: The Hue-Saturation-Value model was created by A. R. Smith in 1978. It is based on such intuitive color characteristics as tint, shade and tone (or family, purity and intensity). The coordinate system is cylindrical, and the colors are defined inside a hexcone. The hue value H runs from 0 to 360. The saturation S is the degree of strength or purity and is from 0 to 1. Purity is how much white is added to the color, so S=1 makes the purest color (no white). The brightness V also ranges from 0 to 1, where 0 is black. Both the saturation and the brightness value can be thought of as percentages, ranging from 0% (0) to 100% (1).

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.HsvColor.Hue
member.summary: Gets the hue.
member.remarks: The hue lies in the range [0..360]. The default value is 360.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.HsvColor.Saturation
member.summary: Gets the saturation.
member.remarks: The saturation lies in the range [0..1]. The default value is 1.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.HsvColor.Value
member.summary: Gets the value.
member.remarks: The value lies in the range [0..1]. The default value is 1.

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The hue.
The saturation.
The value.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.HsvColor.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string that represents the current object.
member.remarks: This method is intended ONLY for development, debugging, and testing purposes. It returns a string in the format "Hue: {0:F2}, Saturation: {1:F2}, Value: {2:F2}", using a precision of two decimals for each of the three values. It uses the to prevent issues with decimal symbols and other locale dependencies. Do not use the result of this method in the user interface.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.PresentationTheme

member.remarks: The WPF Toolkit supports a number of presentation themes. These include the dark and the light variant of the Experience Identity, as well as the various Design Language System (sDLS) themes. This enumeration defines all the supported presentation themes.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ResourceUtility
member.summary: Utility class that contains helper methods for handling resources.

remarks.para: This utility class provides some helper methods to perform frequently used operations, such as loading a XAML icon (an ) from a resource dictionary.
This utility class also provides a convenience layer on top of the class, making it easier to access the URI's for the resource dictionaries that are associated with the various values.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ResourceUtility.BaseUriPrefix
member.summary: Gets the base URI prefix.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ResourceUtility.IconUriPrefix
member.summary: Gets the URI prefix that points to the location of the Experience Identity icons.
member.remarks: This constant string can be used to prefix the URI of Experience Identity icons that are embedded in the WPF Toolkit assembly. Please be aware that this is only a subset of the complete set of Experience Identity icons - only those icons that are actually used by the controls and the custom controls of the WPF Toolkit itself are embedded in the assembly; all other icons are not, they are deployed independent of the WPF Toolkit assembly. This means that you have to be very careful when you use this prefix, as you need to be sure that the icon is actually embedded in the assembly. Therefore, we advice to not use this constant, unless you are implementing a control or a custom control in the WPF Toolkit itself.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ResourceUtility.DlsIconUriPrefix
member.summary: Gets the URI prefix that points to the location of the sDLS icons.
member.remarks: This constant string can be used to prefix the URI of sDLS icons that are embedded in the WPF Toolkit assembly. Please be aware that this is only a subset of the complete set of sDLS icons - only those icons that are actually used by the controls and the custom controls of the WPF Toolkit itself are embedded in the assembly; all other icons are not, they are deployed independent of the WPF Toolkit assembly. This means that you have to be very careful when you use this prefix, as you need to be sure that the icon is actually embedded in the assembly. Therefore, we advice to not use this constant, unless you are implementing a control or a custom control in the WPF Toolkit itself.

Most of the icons in this list are only here because they are erroneously designed as multicolor icons. These icons need to be removed again once properly designed monochrome variants become available.

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ResourceUtility.LoadCursor(System.String)
member.overloads: Loads the specified by the cursor name.
member.summary: Loads the Experience Identity specified by the cursor name.

remarks.para: The cursor name is taken to represent the name of the cursor file, minus the usual cursor file extension ".cur". This method assumes that the cursor is present as a resource within the WPF Toolkit assembly. So, for example, if you want to load the cursor called "ZoomCursor.cur", you call this method with "ZoomCursor" for the parameter.
The creation of a new instance is locked, so that multi-threading issues are avoided.

member.param: The name of the cursor file to load.
member.returns: The loaded , or if no cursor corresponding to the could be loaded.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.ThemeAndCultureUtility
member.summary: Utility class that contains helper methods for handling theme and culture switching.

remarks.para: It is particularly important to use this utility when from is used to optimize application startup speed by reusing already loaded dictionaries.

This utility class also exposes a property that allows application builders to define, at the level of the WPF Toolkit, whether those controls provided by the WPF Toolkit that display a date and/or a time, should by default use the harmonized culture, or the local or operating system culture. WPF Toolkit controls that are affected by this property include the , the , the , and the , as all of these controls by their nature display a date and/or a time.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.DictionaryCachingMode
member.summary: Enumeration defining the possible modes of dictionary caching.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.DictionaryCachingMode.Disabled
member.summary: Disabled, resource dictionaries will be loaded every time they are referenced.

member.name: F:Philips.Platform.Presentation.DictionaryCachingMode.Enabled
member.summary: Enabled, when a second instance of the resource dictionary with the same source is created, it is only merged from the cache.

members.member:
The shared resource dictionary is a specialized that loads its content only once. If a second instance with the same source is created, it only merges the resources from the cache.
This ResourceDictionary implementation addresses a startup performance issue. Time is saved by preventing loading of the same resource dictionaries multiple times.
The shared resource dictionary is meant for internal use only. It should be used with care by customers.
/// Taken from http://wpftutorial.net/MergedDictionaryPerformance.html

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.UIFinder.FindTemplatePart(System.Windows.Controls.Control,System.String)
member.summary: Finds the named template part for the specified control.

remarks.para: This extension method allows you to get a named template part for a control in code behind. This can be useful if you need to access a template part which you know is there, but which is otherwise inaccessible through the control's API.

Please be aware that the named template parts will, in general, only be accessible after the control's template has been applied, i.e., after the method has been called. Calling this extension method earlier than that may result in not being able to find the named template part, simply because the control has not been completed yet. Therefore, you should always check the result of this extension method for .

member.param: The control for which to find the named template part.
The name of the template part. Typically, a named template part starts with the prefix "PART_". This method does not assume that this convention if followed, though.
member.returns: The named template part for the specified control, or if no such template part can be found.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.DoubleRangeValidationRule
member.summary: Validation rule that validates whether a text input can be parsed as a double that lies within a specified range, determined by a minimum and a maximum.
member.remarks: This validation rule can be used as a generic rule to validate that text input represents a double within a specified range. The range is specified by setting the validation rule's and properties. The method will return a if the text input can be parsed as a double that lies within the specified range; otherwise, it will return a with localized error content, which can be displayed as a tooltip to give the user a hint of what is expected of her/him.
member.example:
The following example shows how to create a required text input field for entry of the weight:
<TextBox> <TextBox.Text> <Binding Path="Weight" UpdateSourceTrigger="PropertyChanged"> <Binding.ValidationRules> <ptc:DoubleRangeValidationRule Minimum="0.0" Maximum="300.0" ValidationStep="RawProposedValue" ValidatesOnTargetUpdated="True"/> </Binding.ValidationRules> </Binding> </TextBox.Text> </TextBox>

member.summary: Validates whether the specified input value can be parsed as a double that lies within the range specified by the and properties.
member.param: The value from the binding target to check.
The culture to use in this rule.
member.returns: , if the input value can be parsed as a double that lies within the specified range; or a with localized error content, otherwise.

member.remarks: By default, the value of this property is 0.0 (similar to ).

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.IntegerRangeValidationRule
member.summary: Validation rule that validates whether a text input can be parsed as an integer that lies within a specified range, determined by a minimum and a maximum.
member.remarks: This validation rule can be used as a generic rule to validate that text input represents an integer within a specified range. The range is specified by setting the validation rule's and properties. The method will return a if the text input can be parsed as an integer that lies within the specified range; otherwise, it will return a with localized error content, which can be displayed as a tooltip to give the user a hint of what is expected of her/him.
member.example:
The following example shows how to create a required text input field for entry of the age:
<TextBox> <TextBox.Text> <Binding Path="Age" UpdateSourceTrigger="PropertyChanged"> <Binding.ValidationRules> <ptc:IntegerRangeValidationRule Minimum="0" Maximum="150" ValidationStep="RawProposedValue" ValidatesOnTargetUpdated="True"/> </Binding.ValidationRules> </Binding> </TextBox.Text> </TextBox>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.IntegerRangeValidationRule.Validate(System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Validates whether the specified input value can be parsed as an integer that lies within the range specified by the and properties.
member.param: The value from the binding target to check.
The culture to use in this rule.
member.returns: , if the input value can be parsed as an integer that lies within the specified range; or a with localized error content, otherwise.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.IntegerRangeValidationRule.Minimum
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum, i.e., the lower boundary of the range.
member.remarks: By default, the value of this property is 0 (similar to ).

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.IntegerRangeValidationRule.Maximum
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum, i.e., the upper boundary of the range.
member.remarks: By default, the value of this property is .

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PasswordValidationRule
member.summary: Custom validation rule that validates whether the password provided by the user is valid.

remarks.para: This validation rule can be used to validate the password provided by the user. Validation of user credentials such as username and password is mostly done by the business logic. Therefore, the current validation rule cannot contain any logic to determine whether a given password is valid. This validation rule only exists to provide a mechanism for communicating the result of such a validation to the user interface. The mechanism is very simple and works as follows. This validation rule is bound to the password input field, and it will provide an error message in case the provided password is invalid. The validation proper is done by business logic, which communicates the validation result by setting the static property on this validation rule class.

This validation rule can be used to validate a password independently from other user credentials, such as a username. If it is necessary to validate the username and the password in combination with each other, it is preferable to use another validation rule called the .

member.example:
The following example shows how to create a password input field which has this validation rule attached to it.
<PasswordBox> <PasswordBox.Uid> <Binding Path="BindableDummy" RelativeSource="{RelativeSource TemplatedParent}" Mode="TwoWay" UpdateSourceTrigger="PropertyChanged"> <Binding.ValidationRules> <ptc:PasswordValidationRule/> </Binding.ValidationRules> </Binding> </PasswordBox.Uid> </PasswordBox>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PasswordValidationRule.Validate(System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Validates the password provided by the user.
member.remarks: The actual validation of the password is done by the business logic, outside of this validation rule class. The validation result is communicated via the static property . This Validate method merely checks the value of that property to determine whether the provided input is valid or invalid.
member.returns: , if the password provided by the user is valid; or a with localized error content, otherwise.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.PasswordValidationRule.IsValid
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the provided password is valid.
member.remarks: The actual validation of the password is done by the business logic, outside of this validation rule class. This static property merely exists as a hook for the business logic to communicate the results of the validation.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.RequiredTextInputValidationRule
member.summary: Validation rule that validates whether a required text input field has received input.
member.remarks: This validation rule can be used as a generic rule to validate whether a required text input field has received input. The method will return a if the text input field has indeed received input that is not null or the empty string. It will return a indicating that this is a required text input field as long as no valid text input has been received.
member.example:
The following example shows how to create a required text input field for entry of the patient name:
<TextBox> <TextBox.Text> <Binding Path="PatientName" UpdateSourceTrigger="PropertyChanged"> <Binding.ValidationRules> <ptc:RequiredTextInputValidationRule ValidationStep="RawProposedValue" ValidatesOnTargetUpdated="True"/> </Binding.ValidationRules> </Binding> </TextBox.Text> </TextBox>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.RequiredTextInputValidationRule.Validate(System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Validates whether the specified value is a non-empty .
member.param: The value from the binding target to check.
The culture to use in this validation rule.
member.returns: , if the specified value is a non-empty string (indicating that the text input field to which this validation rule applies has received non-empty text input); or a which indicates that no text input has been received, otherwise.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.UserNamePasswordValidationRule
member.summary: Custom validation rule that validates whether the username and password provided by the user are valid.

remarks.para: This validation rule can be used to validate the username and the password provided by the user. Validation of user credentials such as username and password is mostly done by the business logic. Therefore, the current validation rule cannot contain any logic to determine whether a given username and password combination is valid. This validation rule only exists to provide a mechanism for communicating the result of such a validation to the user interface. The mechanism is very simple and works as follows. This validation rule is bound to both the username and password input fields, and it will provide an error message in case the provided username and password combination is invalid, without specifying which of the two is causing the validation error. The validation proper is done by business logic, which communicates the validation result by setting the static property on this validation rule class.

This validation rule can be used to validate a username and password combination, without being specific as to whether it is the username or the password that might be invalid. If it is necessary to validate the username and the password independently, it is preferable to user other validation rules called and , which are better suited for this purpose.

member.example:
The following example shows how to create a username text input field which has this validation rule attached to it.
<TextBox> <TextBox.Text> <Binding Path="UserName" RelativeSource="{RelativeSource TemplatedParent}" Mode="TwoWay" UpdateSourceTrigger="PropertyChanged"> <Binding.ValidationRules> <ptc:UserNamePasswordValidationRule/> </Binding.ValidationRules> </Binding> </TextBox.Text> </TextBox>

member.name: M:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.UserNamePasswordValidationRule.Validate(System.Object,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Validates the username and the password provided by the user.
member.remarks: The actual validation of the username and password is done by the business logic, outside of this validation rule class. The validation result is communicated via the static property . This Validate method merely checks the value of that property to determine whether the provided input is valid or invalid.
member.param: The value from the binding target to check.
The culture to use in this rule.
member.returns: , if the username and password provided by the user are valid; or a with localized error content, otherwise.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.Controls.UserNamePasswordValidationRule.IsValid
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the provided username and password are valid.
member.remarks: The actual validation of the username and password is done by the business logic, outside of this validation rule class. This static property merely exists as a hook for the business logic to communicate the results of the validation.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.AssemblyProperties
member.summary: Defines a number of properties that are associated with the WPF Toolkit assembly.

remarks.para: This class can be used to decrease the dependency of client code on hard-coded values relating to various Presentation Toolkit assembly properties. The main property of interest here is the property, which can be used to construct instances that reference WPF Toolkit resources. The other properties can be derived using reflection via the class. They are included here for the sake of convenience, because they are the constituent parts of the URI prefix.
The use of this class can be convenient to prevent cohabitation issues.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.AssemblyProperties.AssemblyName
member.summary: Gets the assembly name of the Presentation Toolkit assembly.
member.remarks: This property returns the value "Philips.Platform.Presentation".

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.AssemblyProperties.AssemblyVersion
member.summary: Gets the assembly version of the Presentation Toolkit assembly.
member.remarks: This property returns a instance consisting of a and a version number.

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.AssemblyProperties.PublicKeyToken
member.summary: Gets the public key token of the Presentation Toolkit assembly.
member.remarks: This property returns the value "223d991ebf2e6ef5".

member.name: P:Philips.Platform.Presentation.AssemblyProperties.UriPrefix
member.summary: Gets the prefix that can be used to construct instances that reference resources from the Presentation Toolkit assembly.

remarks.para: This property returns the value "/Philips.Platform.Presentation;vMM.mm.0.0;223d991ebf2e6ef5;", where MM denotes the major version number, and mm denotes the minor version number.
Please note that this value is an URI prefix, it is not a full URI.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.TreatAsPublicAttribute
member.summary: Code with this attribute though internal should be treated as public due to agreed/by design InternalVisibleTo/Reflection access
member.remarks: One could consider using the regular .NET framework to give compilation level feedback on proposal state, though that has some drawbacks. Using such an approach for proposed API will very likely cause the related warnings to be suppressed making the annotation as 'obsolete' with message 'proposed' ineffective. Hence the proposed annotation is an informational only at this point.

member.name: T:Philips.Platform.Presentation.DeprecatedApiAttribute
member.summary: Code with this attribute will be removed in the near future. Please update using code to use the alternative as stated in the .
member.remarks: One could consider using the regular .NET framework Using such an approach for an deprecated API will very likely cause the related warnings to be suppressed making the annotation as deprecated ineffective. With the deprecated we also indicate a grace period. Hence the deprecated annotation is an informational only at this point.
